quotes.quote_raw: I don't think he will fully be able to get his methodologies across because some of the players don't come back from international duty until late in the week. I also don’t think Erik ten Hag was that far from getting things right - in terms of on the pitch - so I don’t think it’s wholesale changes.
quotes.quote_summary: The new manager might struggle initially due to players returning late from international duty. Ten Hag had almost got things right on the pitch, so no major changes are needed.
quotes.speaker: Andros Townsend

quotes.quote_raw: There are times this season when I have watched them and they have almost been there in terms of their performance. They would play well and create chances but they didn't have Rasmus Hojlund fit or any other number nine to put those chances away.
quotes.quote_summary: Man Utd's performance has been nearly there this season; they created chances but lacked a fit striker to finish them.
quotes.speaker: Andros Townsend

quotes.quote_raw: Ten Hag's philosophy was to press high but the likes of Garnacho have been injured and Mason Mount has hardly been available during his reign. He was unfortunate that he didn't have the players that he spent big money on available to implement his philosophy to the fullest.
quotes.quote_summary: Ten Hag's high-pressing philosophy was hampered by injuries and unavailability of key players like Garnacho and Mount.
quotes.speaker: Andros Townsend

quotes.quote_raw: It is just minor tweaks, so it is not going to take a million years for him to get the team he wants and the way he wants to play.
quotes.quote_summary: Only minor adjustments are needed, so the manager should quickly get the team playing as he desires.
quotes.speaker: Andros Townsend

quotes.quote_raw: Amorin’s biggest problem from now until Christmas is going to be time on the training pitch.
quotes.quote_summary: Amorim's main challenge until Christmas will be limited training time.
quotes.speaker: Andros Townsend

quotes.quote_raw: I still think there needs to be massive patience for Amorim. He needs a lot of time.
quotes.quote_summary: People need to be very patient with Amorim; he requires significant time.
quotes.speaker: Chris Sutton

quotes.quote_raw: In terms of expectations for this season - I don’t think they’re a team that is capable of finishing in a Champions League spot.
quotes.quote_summary: I don't believe they can secure a Champions League spot this season.
quotes.speaker: Chris Sutton

quotes.quote_raw: I think there are going to be teething issues at first and this season will still be a bit of a struggle. That is based on what we have seen at Sporting Lisbon and how strong he is in his principles of how he wants to play the game.
quotes.quote_summary: I anticipate initial struggles this season based on Amorim's time at Sporting and his firm principles.
quotes.speaker: Joe McGrath

quotes.quote_raw: Hopefully, we can still do something in a cup, but I think we will finish sixth in the league. I expect towards the end of this campaign to see us start to click.
quotes.quote_summary: We might achieve something in a cup competition, but I predict a sixth-place league finish, improving towards the end of the season.
quotes.speaker: Joe McGrath

quotes.quote_raw: I also expect there to be stars for this team that come out of nowhere but fit his style and formation. It might be players we have not rated in the past but step it up under him.
quotes.quote_summary: I expect some unexpected players will emerge as stars under Amorim, those who suit his style.
quotes.speaker: Joe McGrath

quotes.quote_raw: It is a huge privilege to be given the chance to manage Manchester United. There are only a few people who ever get the opportunity to manage at that level.
quotes.quote_summary: Managing Manchester United is a huge privilege and a rare opportunity.
quotes.speaker: David Moyes

quotes.quote_raw: I haven't managed at Real Madrid but, for me, Manchester United is a club which has bigger support worldwide. Every newspaper in the world would have been covering this story, because there are so many Manchester United supporters worldwide.
quotes.quote_summary: Manchester United has a larger global fanbase than even Real Madrid, making it a significant job.
quotes.speaker: David Moyes

quotes.quote_raw: So it is an incredible job, but it is different as well. I have to say that it carries a lot of pressure and an awful lot of media coverage. They are always looking for things on Manchester United.
quotes.quote_summary: It's an incredible but demanding job, with intense pressure and media scrutiny.
quotes.speaker: David Moyes

quotes.quote_raw: It might take a little bit of time for him to settle in but, if he gets given the time by the board, his statistics and what he's doing at the moment shows up very well in Portugal.
quotes.quote_summary: He might need time to adjust, but his track record in Portugal is excellent.
quotes.speaker: David Moyes

quotes.quote_raw: The most important thing for me at this moment is to create the principles, the identity and the character we had in the past. We will focus a lot on our game model - how to play, how to press, these small things. You cannot go 100% on every detail because it will be confusing for the players. But if I have to say one thing, my main goal, my first goal, it is identity.
quotes.quote_summary: My priority is establishing the principles, identity, and character we previously had, focusing on our game model, especially how we play and press.  Building an identity is my primary goal.
quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim

quotes.quote_raw: We want to do something special in a special club - that was a key point. When Manchester United told me about their plans, you get excited. We know if the team plays well and wins games, everything looks so much better and the people really start to believe in the new stadium and new ideas.
quotes.quote_summary: We aim to achieve something special at this club. United's plans are exciting. Success will build belief in the new stadium and ideas.
quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim

quotes.quote_raw: It's a real honour that I was the first choice to start that path.
quotes.quote_summary: I'm honored to be the chosen one to lead this journey.
quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim

quotes.quote_raw: There has been some pressure on players carrying an injury going into international breaks with their national side because you are contracted to these clubs and that is where your income is. But, for me, as a player I had a similar [mindset to Harry Kane](https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/articles/cp8x4rvne86o) that I would always be available - injured or not injured. I would have injections when I was on international duty just so I could represent my country because it meant that much.
quotes.quote_summary: Despite pressure from clubs, playing for my country was paramount, even if injured. I'd take injections to represent my nation.
quotes.speaker: Fara Williams

quotes.quote_raw: It is difficult, however. If you look at Jack Grealish and [Pep Guardiola's comments,](https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/articles/cvgknzd9gqwo) he has a point because the forward has not been able to play for Manchester City because of injuries. So if you have been sidelined for three or four games, I would agree that you are then not fit and available to go on international duty.
quotes.quote_summary: It's a complex issue.  Guardiola is right to be concerned about Grealish; players sidelined for multiple games shouldn't be on international duty.
quotes.speaker: Fara Williams

quotes.quote_raw: But when you look at some of the other players, ones who have been playing and being managed by their club, then I do not see it being different to being played and managed by your country.
quotes.quote_summary: If players are playing for their club, I see no difference in playing for their country.
quotes.speaker: Fara Williams

quotes.quote_raw: From the club's side, when they are competing at such high levels in the Premier League, you can understand why they would want their players to be rested and get fully fit again over the two weeks, rather than having to come back straight into a hectic period of fixtures.
quotes.quote_summary: Clubs want their players rested during international breaks, especially given the Premier League's intensity.
quotes.speaker: Fara Williams

quotes.quote_raw: I kind of get it from both points of view but, as a player, if I am half fit and being played by my club, I would be fully available for my national team.
quotes.quote_summary: I understand both perspectives, but as a player, I'd always prioritize my national team.
quotes.speaker: Fara Williams

quotes.quote_raw: It is really difficult with the pressure that is on the players, though. I would not look at it as a decision players have made solely.
quotes.quote_summary: The pressure on players is immense regarding international duty; it's not solely their decision.
quotes.speaker: Fara Williams

quotes.quote_raw: There was a lot of speculation about his future. Arsenal reportedly offered him a scholarship contract and a professional deal, but I think he just decided that Manchester United is a better opportunity in terms of his development.
quotes.quote_summary: There was much speculation about Obi-Martin's future. Arsenal offered contracts, but he felt Manchester United was better for his development.
quotes.speaker: Jeorge Bird

quotes.quote_raw: The situation went on for quite a long time but now he has finally signed for United and is playing really well. It could prove to be a good decision for him in the end.
quotes.quote_summary: After a long period of uncertainty, he signed for United, where he's playing well. It seems to be a positive move for him.
quotes.speaker: Jeorge Bird

quotes.quote_raw: Very. But they might have to be a little bit patient as well.
quotes.quote_summary: United fans should be very excited but patient.
quotes.speaker: Jeorge Bird

quotes.quote_raw: He needs to play more for the under-21s first. If he played about 10 games at that level, then he might be ready for the first team.
quotes.quote_summary: He needs more experience with the under-21s, around 10 games, before he's ready for the first team.
quotes.speaker: Jeorge Bird

quotes.quote_raw: Even right now, he could do well as a substitute in cup games, but they will have to show a little bit of patience with him. Next season is more likely to be the time when he is pushing for first-team involvement, but he definitely has a lot of potential.
quotes.quote_summary: He could potentially be a substitute in cup games, but next season is more realistic for first-team involvement. He has a lot of potential.
quotes.speaker: Jeorge Bird

quotes.quote_raw: He is a really talented player. I watched him quite a few times for the Arsenal academy teams last season and he scored 32 goals for the under-18s, which was a record at that level for the club.
quotes.quote_summary: He's a very talented player. He broke Arsenal's under-18 scoring record with 32 goals last season.
quotes.speaker: Jeorge Bird

quotes.quote_raw: It is outrageous to score that many goals at that level. You normally get one or two players every few years who score quite a few goals, but no-one normally scores that many.
quotes.quote_summary: Scoring that many goals at youth level is remarkable. Very few players achieve such high numbers.
quotes.speaker: Jeorge Bird

quotes.quote_raw: At the beginning of the season he wasn't actually scoring that many goals but he just suddenly started to score and was playing with a lot of confidence. The way the Arsenal team played last season really suited how he played, which helps, but he just got into the right positions all the time. He knew where to run and was playing with so much confidence.
quotes.quote_summary: His scoring picked up significantly mid-season. Arsenal's style suited him, but his positioning and confidence were key.
quotes.speaker: Jeorge Bird

quotes.quote_raw: This season, Arsenal have found it a bit difficult without him and that shows how well he did.
quotes.quote_summary: Arsenal have struggled without him, demonstrating his value.
quotes.speaker: Jeorge Bird

quotes.quote_raw: Some people say he has a major advantage to those around him because he is so tall compared with other players at that level. It will be interesting to see when he plays against senior players whether he can still be as prolific, but he has really good qualities.
quotes.quote_summary: His height is advantageous at youth level. It remains to be seen if he maintains his prolific scoring against senior players, but he has excellent attributes.
quotes.speaker: Jeorge Bird

quotes.quote_raw: He can control the ball really well, he is quite quick and can get into good spaces. He is going to be a really good player but it will interesting to see how he does at a higher level.
quotes.quote_summary: He has good ball control, speed, and positioning. He'll be a great player, but his performance at a higher level remains to be seen.
quotes.speaker: Jeorge Bird

quotes.quote_raw: If Ruben Amorim had gone straight into Manchester United off the back of Erik ten Hag's sacking, I would have given him different priorities on his to-do list than what he has now. After Ruud van Nistelrooy's four games in charge, it is a different conversation with the players. Their confidence is already higher - you can see that in the performances - and that would have been something he would have looked at early on.
quotes.quote_summary: Amorim's priorities would be different had he taken over directly after Ten Hag.  Van Nistelrooy boosted player confidence, which is a key change.
quotes.speaker: Fara Williams

quotes.quote_raw: One of his first priorities now will be getting to know the players. When a manager first comes in, you can change who you are as a player a little bit in those first few weeks. You want to impress and players and managers are working each other out. But he will know the ones trying to pull the wool over his eyes and the players will know that with him. You must build those relationships early.
quotes.quote_summary: Getting to know the players is crucial.  Players try to impress new managers, but Amorim will see through any facades. Building relationships early is essential.
quotes.speaker: Fara Williams

quotes.quote_raw: Amorim needs to identify the areas of development that these players need, individually and collectively. Have those conversations and find out how players are feeling given the pressure they have been under with results.
quotes.quote_summary: Amorim must identify areas for player development, both individual and collective, and understand how they're coping with the pressure.
quotes.speaker: Fara Williams

quotes.quote_raw: However, trying to understand players in a short space of time is difficult and he will be learning about them on the job.
quotes.quote_summary: Quickly understanding players is tough; Amorim will learn on the job.
quotes.speaker: Fara Williams

quotes.quote_raw: The international break provides an added challenge, particularly with the style of play Amorim has. For players, the training sessions at clubs during this time are a lot shorter. It is less tactical and more focused on individual stuff so Amorim will not be able to get a lot of his philosophy and ideas across to players.
quotes.quote_summary: The international break is challenging, especially with Amorim's style, as club training is shorter and less tactical during this period.
quotes.speaker: Fara Williams

quotes.quote_raw: Manchester United is a massive club and what this does is give the new boss time to see what the place is about. He will have more time to do that coming in during an international break than he would have done if he came in with back-to-back games straight away.
quotes.quote_summary: The international break gives Amorim more time to acclimate to Manchester United.
quotes.speaker: Fara Williams

quotes.quote_raw: You watch on TV and you know that it's big and it's impressive - but when you are here, you can feel it and I think you feel the history. I'm really, really proud to be a Manchester United coach, so it's amazing. It's a real honour to be here.
quotes.quote_summary: The club's size and history are truly felt when you're here. I'm incredibly proud and honored to be the Manchester United coach.
quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim

quotes.quote_raw: That's really funny because I feel very relaxed. Maybe because it’s not gameday. When we have a game I'm a different guy, but I really don't feel the weight. I'm really excited and I'm quite relaxed. I think I am where I am supposed to be. That's the feeling.
quotes.quote_summary: Surprisingly, I'm very relaxed, perhaps because it's not a matchday. I don't feel the pressure. I'm excited and feel I'm in the right place.
quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim

quotes.quote_raw: He comes Ennis again. He's been excellent again, hasn't he? He's really lively
quotes.quote_summary: Ennis has been excellent and lively.
quotes.speaker: Altrincham's commentator

quotes.quote_raw: Lovely pillows with that crunchy hotel feel. Extremely comfy, full bounce-back.
quotes.quote_summary: These pillows feel like comfortable hotel pillows.
quotes.speaker: Reviewer

quotes.quote_raw: All the smoke was coming out of the house.
quotes.quote_summary: The house was filled with smoke.
quotes.speaker: Witness

quotes.quote_raw: We want to create a safe space for people.
quotes.quote_summary: Our aim is to provide a safe environment.
quotes.speaker: Snooker lounge representative

quotes.quote_raw: Let's be honest, if it wasn't for John Henry Davies, the brewer, and James Gibson there would be no Manchester United now. He rebuilt the club not once but twice. People forget that Old Trafford was a bomb site after the war and it all started when he attended a dinner.
quotes.quote_summary: Without John Henry Davies and James Gibson, Manchester United wouldn't exist. Gibson rebuilt the club twice, including Old Trafford after the war.
quotes.speaker: Alan Embling

quotes.quote_raw: He was approached by a journalist who told him United were in a terrible state and nobody wanted to help them, so he said he would look at it and looked at the books.
quotes.quote_summary: A journalist informed Gibson of United's dire situation, prompting him to examine the club's finances.
quotes.speaker: Alan Embling

quotes.quote_raw: The finances were a total disaster, all the good players had been sold off and the supporters were leaving in droves, but he gave a cheque of £2,000 and it was a gift, no strings attached.
quotes.quote_summary: United's finances were disastrous, players were sold, and fans were leaving, but Gibson donated £2,000 without conditions.
quotes.speaker: Alan Embling

quotes.quote_raw: They hadn't being paying the players' salaries for a long time and there was a huge backlog. It was just before Christmas and he covered the salaries up to January with the promise that he would see if he could help further, and he thought there was enough room in Manchester for two football clubs.
quotes.quote_summary: Gibson covered the players' overdue salaries before Christmas, promising to assess further assistance, believing Manchester could support two clubs.
quotes.speaker: Alan Embling

quotes.quote_raw: He decided to help and he did. He became the chairman and part of the £2,000 was so the players could buy the biggest Turkeys they could get their hands on for Christmas.
quotes.quote_summary: Gibson became chairman and used some of the £2,000 to ensure the players had a good Christmas.
quotes.speaker: Alan Embling

quotes.quote_raw: However, they were losing games and supporters were disappearing, so he held a meeting with fans and started to turn the club around. He rebuilt the club and it was incredible.
quotes.quote_summary: Despite initial struggles, Gibson engaged with fans and successfully turned the club around.
quotes.speaker: Alan Embling

quotes.quote_raw: At that time, Old Trafford was quite a way out, it was isolated, so he negotiated with the railway authorities to stop passenger trains on matchdays so fans could use the trains to get to the games on matchdays.
quotes.quote_summary: Gibson improved transport links to Old Trafford by arranging for trains to stop there on matchdays.
quotes.speaker: Alan Embling

quotes.quote_raw: James Gibson always considered supporters, who were the most important thing to him. However, he was paying transfer fees from his own pocket the whole time, so what he did with Walter Crickmer was create MUJAC, which stood for Manchester United Junior Athletic Club.
quotes.quote_summary: Gibson prioritized supporters and, to address funding transfer fees, created MUJAC, the precursor to the youth academy.
quotes.speaker: Alan Embling

quotes.quote_raw: That was the foundation and the start of the youth policy, which was the first in the country, and the only thing he said was he wanted as much local youth as possible. He wanted to support them, he was very community minded and he wanted to do it for the local people.
quotes.quote_summary: MUJAC was the foundation of the first youth policy in the country, prioritizing local talent.
quotes.speaker: Alan Embling

quotes.quote_raw: Gibson was a man of vision, he was ahead of his time. He'd been very lucky, he'd made a lot of money and was a hard working businessman, and the benefit of that was he was able to save Manchester United from extinction because the bank had closed on them.
quotes.quote_summary: Gibson's vision and business acumen allowed him to save Manchester United from bankruptcy.
quotes.speaker: Alan Embling

quotes.quote_raw: People had very little in their lives at that time and mostly going to the football after they worked hard all week was there only form of enjoyment. He gave that pleasure back to the people.
quotes.quote_summary: Gibson restored the joy of football to the people, which was their primary source of entertainment at the time.
quotes.speaker: Alan Embling

quotes.quote_raw: By running a team in the Manchester League, we shall be able to give all likely juniors a chance of showing their paces, and United hope to discover from their number more than average finds.
quotes.quote_summary: Our Manchester League team will allow promising juniors to showcase their skills, hoping to uncover exceptional talent.
quotes.speaker: Scott Duncan

quotes.quote_raw: We will develop their muscles and build up their frame so that in time they could step in [to the first-team] and do themselves justice.
quotes.quote_summary: We'll physically develop youngsters so they're ready for the first-team.
quotes.speaker: Scott Duncan

quotes.quote_raw: To hurry along a youngster is a big mistake, but the junior must be assured that his time will come.
quotes.quote_summary: Rushing young players is a mistake, but they must be assured of their future opportunity.
quotes.speaker: Scott Duncan

quotes.quote_raw: The war smashed the whole lot down. He managed to rebuild it on a shoe string budget because houses, factories and everything took precedence over sporting facilities.
quotes.quote_summary: The war destroyed Old Trafford, and Gibson rebuilt it with a limited budget due to other priorities.
quotes.speaker: Alan Embling

quotes.quote_raw: And whilst he was busy negotiating with the government for United to get their grants and licence to rebuild, he helped nine other football clubs to get their grants to rebuild their stadiums.
quotes.quote_summary: While securing funding for Old Trafford's reconstruction, Gibson helped nine other clubs get grants for their stadiums.
quotes.speaker: Alan Embling

quotes.quote_raw: United were lucky a lot of the youngsters came back and the only condition he put on them was if they were good enough to play professionally, they would be considered. There was no 'you've got to play them', it was 'consider' and one of the first names was Charlie Mitten.
quotes.quote_summary: Many young players returned after the war and Gibson's only condition was that they be considered for professional play if good enough.
quotes.speaker: Alan Embling

quotes.quote_raw: I'm the only living person now who knew James Gibson. I can remember him before he had a stroke, but mainly, of course, my memories are from after the stroke.
quotes.quote_summary: I'm the last living person who knew James Gibson, primarily remembering him after his stroke.
quotes.speaker: Alan Embling

quotes.quote_raw: He didn't go to the '48 FA Cup final because of that stroke and was presented with the cup in his home. That was incredible and he told Matt Busby that he'd made his dreams come true.
quotes.quote_summary: Due to a stroke, Gibson couldn't attend the '48 FA Cup final but received the cup at home, expressing to Busby that his dreams were fulfilled.
quotes.speaker: Alan Embling

quotes.quote_raw: Unfortunately as I got older, I found out that a lot of people didn't know who James Gibson was and what he did has all been eroded away, which is wrong.
quotes.quote_summary: It's unfortunate that Gibson's legacy has been forgotten.
quotes.speaker: Alan Embling

quotes.quote_raw: What that man did was incredible. He didn't even cash from merchandising, sponsorship or the television and we've even found clothing coupons that he provided for the kits.
quotes.quote_summary: Gibson's contributions were remarkable, even providing clothing coupons for kits without personal financial gain.
quotes.speaker: Alan Embling

quotes.quote_raw: The Gibsons were a dying breed. They were the people who looked after supporters, but when the big sponsorships came in, the big money men came in and fans were forgotten about. So much has been lost. United was like a family and you don't have that in the same these days.
quotes.quote_summary: People like Gibson, who prioritized supporters, are rare now. The focus has shifted from fans to financial gains.
quotes.speaker: Alan Embling

quotes.quote_raw: United should play more acknowledgment to two of the greatest men in the club history, James Gibson and John Davies, the brewer, because those two men were incredible.
quotes.quote_summary: United should give more recognition to Gibson and Davies for their immense contributions.
quotes.speaker: Alan Embling

quotes.quote_raw: Without them, there wouldn't be all those people enjoying football at Old Trafford now and I hope if they have to build a new stadium, something is done to keep the memorial.
quotes.quote_summary: Without Gibson and Davies, Old Trafford wouldn't be what it is today, and their memorial should be preserved in any new stadium.
quotes.speaker: Alan Embling

quotes.quote_raw: Dear fans, Let me start by thanking you. Thank you for always being there for the club. Whether it was at a game far away or a tough match at Old Trafford, your support has been unshakeable. The atmosphere at Old Trafford has always been electrifying, thanks to you. I felt it many times. Also in away games, it gave the team and me an incredible feeling to hear the United chants taking over the opponents stadiums, whether the game was in England. Europe or during the summer tours. I always enjoyed meeting Manchester United fans throughout the world. Walking the streets and being able to chat with fans in England, Europe, Asia, Australia, the USA - you inspired me and radiated a strong sense of unity. That's what makes United supporters so special. I want to thank you for giving me this feeling and for your support. I also want to thank the staff in every department of the club for their unwavering support in good times and bad. We won two trophies - achievements that I will cherish for the rest of my life. Of course, my dream was to bring more trophies to the cabinet. Unfortunately, that dream has come to an end. I wish all Manchester United fans nothing but success, trophies and glory. Your support and the warmth I received from everyone at the club helped me feel at home. Thank you for this chapter in my life.
quotes.quote_summary: Thank you to the fans and staff for your unwavering support. Winning two trophies was a highlight, although I dreamt of more.  I wish the club and fans future success.
quotes.speaker: Erik ten Hag

quotes.quote_raw: Lovely pillows with that crunchy hotel feel. Extremely comfy, full bounce-back.
quotes.quote_summary: These pillows feel like premium hotel pillows, very comfortable and springy.
quotes.speaker: Reviewer

quotes.quote_raw: All the smoke was coming out of the house.
quotes.quote_summary: The house was completely filled with smoke.
quotes.speaker: Witness

quotes.quote_raw: We want to create a safe space for people.
quotes.quote_summary: Our aim is to provide a safe environment.
quotes.speaker: Representative of the snooker lounge

quotes.quote_raw: I have played, however, especially last season with coach Ten Hag, deeper. In fact, against Everton, I played No.6 and I still think it was one of the most complete games I've played, at all levels. In terms of passing, game organisation, defence, tactics. I have a little thought in my head that I'm going to end my career further back, because everyone who started there and went to No.10 ended up retreating on the field at the end. It's a position I like, playing deeper, facing the game more. With the ball, it makes my game a lot easier because I have a broader view of the game and it is ideal for what we've talked about with the last pass, which can sometimes come from deeper on the pitch. The game with Everton was the one in which I created the most scoring opportunities, even though I was playing deeper and not playing as a No.10.
quotes.quote_summary: Last season I played deeper, even as a No.6 against Everton, which I felt was one of my most well-rounded performances. I'm considering finishing my career in a deeper role for better game management and passing opportunities, as demonstrated in the Everton match where I created numerous chances despite not playing as a No.10.
quotes.speaker: Bruno Fernandes

quotes.quote_raw: Lovely pillows with that crunchy hotel feel. Extremely comfy, full bounce-back.
quotes.quote_summary: These pillows feel like premium hotel quality, very comfortable.
quotes.speaker: Reviewer

quotes.quote_raw: All the smoke was coming out of the house.
quotes.quote_summary: The house was completely filled with smoke.
quotes.speaker: Witness

quotes.quote_raw: We want to create a safe space for people.
quotes.quote_summary: Our aim is to provide a safe environment.
quotes.speaker: Snooker Lounge Representative

quotes.quote_raw: When I signed for Manchester United, I discovered that in England, during away games, family members don’t have a reserved section; they sit among the fans. The first match was the derby against Liverpool. I told my girlfriend: ‘Look, it’s a very intense match. Do you still want to come?’ And she said: ‘Yes, of course, I really care.’ So, she got in the car with the steering wheel on the right and went into the away section. For a footballer, the English football culture brings less pressure. During the week, there’s less talk about football; the weekend and the experience of going to the stadium are more important.
quotes.quote_summary: In England, families sit with fans at away games. My girlfriend even drove herself to the Liverpool derby! Football culture here is less pressured, focused on the stadium experience.
quotes.speaker: Matteo Darmian

quotes.quote_raw: As soon as I arrived in Manchester, I discovered a completely new world. In Italy, very few players had social media profiles. In England, on my first day, they immediately told me to open an Instagram account and that I would need to participate in commercial initiatives. What now seems normal wasn’t back then. There were so many commercial activities; it was a completely different world from what I was used to. In the following years, Pogba and Ibrahimovic also arrived, and they were media superstars.
quotes.quote_summary: Arriving at Manchester United was a whole new world.  I was immediately told to open an Instagram and participate in commercial activities. It was very different from Italy where few players had social media.  Later, big media stars like Pogba and Ibrahimovic joined.
quotes.speaker: Matteo Darmian

quotes.quote_raw: I think you will see an idea. You could like it or not, I don't know, but you will see an idea. You will see a positioning. You will see something.
quotes.quote_summary: You'll definitely see a clear tactical approach from my team, whether you appreciate it or not.
quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim

quotes.quote_raw: Something that we want to reach that kind of level. You will feel that. But we have to know that it's like two training [sessions] before the first match. This is the best league in the world. But if I have to say something to you, you will see an idea. This I can guarantee.
quotes.quote_summary: We aim for a certain level of play, and you'll sense it, despite only having two training sessions. This league is highly competitive, but I assure you, there will be a noticeable strategy.
quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim

quotes.quote_raw: With a mixture of cautious optimism and suspicion
quotes.quote_summary: We're cautiously optimistic but also suspicious.
quotes.speaker: Alfredo Fumacas

quotes.quote_raw: Of course there's concern from Benfica. Benfica initially brought in Carreras on a loan, but activated the buy clause of €6m in the beginning of the season, knowing that there was a buy back clause of €20m, at the time there were some questions from the fans in terms of his worth. I don't believe Benfica expected Carreras to rise up this quickly and to be on the radar of many European clubs, usually Benfica can keep suitors at bay with high release causes, but €20m will be a bargain for a 21-year-old with lots of potential.
quotes.quote_summary: Benfica are concerned about losing Carreras, especially given his rapid rise and the relatively low buy-back clause. They didn't anticipate his value increasing so fast.
quotes.speaker: Alfredo Fumacas

quotes.quote_raw: On paper he is a good fit, along with doing very well covering the left flank and combining well with his teammates. He has also played as a third centre-half at Benfica during some tactical variations by Lage. He likes to associate with the midfield in the build-up process, and does very well in short combinations, and getting into the final third - reminiscent of Alejandro Grimaldo, but with more of a defensive ability to his game. I feel Carreras is doing well at Benfica because of the trust Lage has put in him, and because he has been able to win the hearts of the fans with his performances. Playing at Old Trafford, where he didn't have the best of times, endured rejection, albeit normal for the process of a young player, may be something that will weigh on his psyche, but we are also talking about a 21 year old Carreras who has evolved mentally with the experiences he's had.
quotes.quote_summary: Carreras is a good fit for United on paper. He's strong defensively and offensively, comfortable playing various roles. While his previous experience at Old Trafford might affect him, he has grown a lot and Lage's trust has been beneficial.
quotes.speaker: Alfredo Fumacas

quotes.quote_raw: probably already has a number of strikers
quotes.quote_summary: United already has enough strikers.
quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim

quotes.quote_raw: we'll see
quotes.quote_summary: We'll see what the future holds.
quotes.speaker: Viktor Gyokeres

quotes.quote_raw: Portuguese clubs have got no option but to sell for the right price. We need to sell. Portuguese clubs have to sell one or two players every season. We don't have the same TV rights as the Premier League so we don't have the capacity to hold on to players. It would be lovely to see Portugal with a little bit more capacity to hold on to their talent, of course.
quotes.quote_summary: Portuguese clubs must sell players to survive financially due to lower TV revenue compared to the Premier League.  We'd prefer to keep our talent, but it's necessary.
quotes.speaker: Jose Fonte

quotes.quote_raw: That's what people in the various federations are trying to do. Sporting will listen and they will probably have to sell Viktor Gyokeres because Portuguese clubs have to raise big money every year.
quotes.quote_summary: Federations are working to change the financial situation, but Sporting likely will have to sell Gyokeres due to financial pressures.
quotes.speaker: Jose Fonte

quotes.quote_raw: Everyone paid more to Viktor, everyone paid a higher commission to the agent. What happened? I brought him to Sporting because of Ruben Amorim, because I know his work and his work with the players. I chose Ruben because he is a coach of another level. And, yes, it will be more difficult for Viktor to stay if Ruben Amorim leaves Sporting because Viktor came precisely because of Ruben. The day we met, we told Ruben: 'here's my boy, he came to Sporting because of you.'
quotes.quote_summary: I brought Gyokeres to Sporting specifically for Amorim; better offers and commissions were available elsewhere. Gyokeres is likely to follow Amorim if he leaves.
quotes.speaker: Hasan Cetinkaya

quotes.quote_raw: It's not something I'm thinking about. I want to finish the season at Sporting, I'm enjoying playing there. I'm in no rush to make a change in the future. We'll see when the time comes for that.
quotes.quote_summary: I'm focused on finishing the season at Sporting and not currently thinking about transferring.
quotes.speaker: Viktor Gyokeres

quotes.quote_raw: The most important thing is to have an important role in the team and be able to play. There are other factors that may play a role, but I will look at that when the time comes.
quotes.quote_summary: Playing a key role will be my priority when considering future transfers.
quotes.speaker: Viktor Gyokeres

quotes.quote_raw: Real Madrid or Atletico? I think maybe he has more of an Atletico de Madrid profile. Physically, he's a beast. Potentially, he's an animal, and in front of goal, he's a killer. It seemed like there was no way he could repeat what he did last year, and there's this amount of goals. Plus, this year, with the protagonism of doing so in the Champions League.
quotes.quote_summary: Gyokeres's playing style, being a strong and prolific scorer, fits Atletico Madrid more than Real Madrid.  He's continued his excellent performance from last year into the Champions League this year.
quotes.speaker: Adan

quotes.quote_raw: Well, I think he has that profile. It's true that he's a little shorter, but in terms of strength, determination in the box, he has that killer instinct of scoring a lot of goals. He shows spectacular competitiveness every day in training.
quotes.quote_summary: Gyokeres has a similar profile to Haaland in terms of strength and goal-scoring instinct, showing his competitiveness daily.
quotes.speaker: Adan

quotes.quote_raw: Correct [top clubs wanted me as a No.2], Manchester United, for example. But that wasn't an option for me. I'm not happy if I can't be on the pitch. I want to enjoy my time on the pitch right now, together with fans and teammates. I want to play for titles and ideally win them too.
quotes.quote_summary: Top clubs like Manchester United wanted me as a backup, but I declined. I want to play regularly, enjoy the game with fans and teammates, and compete for titles.
quotes.speaker: Yvon Mvogo

quotes.quote_raw: Getting promoted again with Lorient next spring is definitely my goal. We will see what happens after that and I don't want to predict anything. I have now noticed how quickly things can happen in the football business.
quotes.quote_summary: My main goal is to help Lorient get promoted. I'll assess my options after that, as things change rapidly in football.
quotes.speaker: Yvon Mvogo

quotes.quote_raw: Every briefing coming out of OT underlines what a cataclysmic mistake it was keeping ten Toast (sic) last summer. They let him spend another £200m+ on rubbish & now there’s nothing for Amorim. Somebody in the brains trust should be fired. There’s nothing for Amorim to work with.
quotes.quote_summary: Keeping Ten Hag last summer was a huge mistake. He wasted over £200m, leaving Amorim with nothing. Someone should be held accountable.
quotes.speaker: Richard Keys

quotes.quote_raw: I do think the players, obviously, get away with murder.
quotes.quote_summary: Players get away with too much.
quotes.speaker: Roy Keane

quotes.quote_raw: Just the way they hide behind the manager, Mourinho. Whatever you say about the players, they have thrown him under the bus. People have said Mourinho has been falling out with players, well you would fall out with players. That's the name of the game, players turn up overweight or players are not training properly and not producing. And then for some of them to down tools, you know, shame on some of them players. I'm not Mourinho's biggest fan, don't get me wrong, but I just can't tolerate footballers who hide behind agents, their pals in the media. A bit of a joke, really.
quotes.quote_summary: The players, not Mourinho, are to blame. Some don't train properly, are overweight, and hide behind their agents and the media. It's shameful.
quotes.speaker: Roy Keane

quotes.quote_raw: Suppose we are in the stands together as a scout for Manchester City or Liverpool... and we are looking at Antony, what do you think we would say when we come back on Monday? We will not take that. You don’t see a Serge Gnabry, Leroy Sane or Mohamed Salah doing this. Then you can say, 'He is young'. But it can also get crazier.
quotes.quote_summary: If we were scouting Antony for City or Liverpool, his behavior would be a major turn-off.  Top players like Gnabry, Sane, or Salah don't act like that, regardless of age.
quotes.speaker: Rene van der Gijp

quotes.quote_raw: He is not that young anymore, because he has been doing this for two years. Such a boy cannot be calmed by a coach, in the end. Ten Hag will of course never say that Antony behaves like an idiot, but he thinks so. In general, this behaviour is addressed in the locker room. Then someone says, 'Hey, what are you doing?'
quotes.quote_summary: He's been acting this way for a while now, and a coach can't fix that.  Even though Ten Hag wouldn't say it publicly, he likely agrees Antony acts foolishly.  This sort of thing gets addressed internally by the team.
quotes.speaker: Wim Kieft

quotes.quote_raw: Top training
quotes.quote_summary: Excellent training session.
quotes.speaker: Casemiro

quotes.quote_raw: Harry Maguire had an issue in the first half and, luckily for us, he overcame and recovered from it. You can see the second half he was up there and then he can express his leadership, he can express his defensive qualities and rest on the ball, we especially needed that in this back four.
quotes.quote_summary: Harry Maguire recovered from a first-half issue and demonstrated his leadership and defensive skills, which were crucial for us.
quotes.speaker: Erik ten Hag

quotes.quote_raw: When United call they get quoted £40million for a player available for £10million.
quotes.quote_summary: Clubs inflate their prices by a large margin when Manchester United shows interest in a player.
quotes.speaker: A figure who deals with recruitment elsewhere in the Premier League

quotes.quote_raw: You're Manchester United, you've got loads of money.
quotes.quote_summary: You're Manchester United, you're rich.
quotes.speaker: John Murtough

quotes.quote_raw: Lovely pillows with that crunchy hotel feel. Extremely comfy, full bounce-back.
quotes.quote_summary: These pillows feel like premium hotel pillows, very comfy and resilient.
quotes.speaker: Unknown

quotes.quote_raw: All the smoke was coming out of the house.
quotes.quote_summary: The house was filled with smoke.
quotes.speaker: Unknown

quotes.quote_raw: We want to create a safe space for people.
quotes.quote_summary: Our goal is to provide a safe environment.
quotes.speaker: Unknown

quotes.quote_raw: It is about a culture and every player has to match certain standards. What will happen there, he knows what he has to do if he wants to return and it is up to him. We will see what will happen.
quotes.quote_summary: It's about the culture and meeting standards. Sancho knows what's required for his return.  It's up to him.
quotes.speaker: Erik ten Hag

quotes.quote_raw: As someone who has played international and Champions League football, I feel extremely lucky to have done so. I also know what is required to get here. A critical element of reaching the top level is making the right decisions for yourself. Many of these decisions stem from ego, something that for me is one of the most important things to keep control of, and can give you a better mentality when used correctly. In football and in life, I have found that, as long as you have a strong mindset and continue to act on it, you can reach new heights. The accolades and recognition you get are a consequence of the decisions you make. If you focus on the process and enjoy the small improvements rather than only focusing on the result, you can always achieve great things.
quotes.quote_summary: Reaching the top level requires making the right decisions and controlling your ego. A strong mindset and focus on the process are key to success.
quotes.speaker: Raphael Varane

quotes.quote_raw: brutal
quotes.quote_summary: The changes at United could be swift and ruthless.
quotes.speaker: Source

quotes.quote_raw: When they're on the pitch, we don't know which is which
quotes.quote_summary: We can't tell the twins apart on the field.
quotes.speaker: Chant

quotes.quote_raw: keep it as low-key as possible
quotes.quote_summary: We're trying to avoid too much attention on the twins.
quotes.speaker: Source

quotes.quote_raw: It tops the list of birthdays. I don’t think words can describe that feeling, seeing the fans, it is everything you’ve dreamed of, coming true. It means everything.
quotes.quote_summary: Making my debut for the club I've supported since childhood on my 19th birthday was an indescribable, dream-come-true experience.
quotes.speaker: Dan Gore

quotes.quote_raw:
He first came through the door when he was seven or eight. Burnley were very good at recruiting the Scouse and Manc kids and Dan was a raw, inner-city Manchester lad. Those types seemed to have that little bit more extra bite than your local kids. He was a forward when he came to us and he’d either play wide left or right or as the number nine and he was the top scorer through his age groups. He was quick and very strong for his size. He always had aggression and he was one of the kids who played on the edge, in terms of maybe making the odd bad challenge, but it was interesting because he was always respectful. He had great finishing ability in his younger years, one-on-one, going past people and he always had that bit where he was a winner. If he was getting beat, there was nobody on the pitch who hated it more and you could see that fire in him. Dan had that brilliant, real f
***** horrible side to him, but he'd always be respectful with coaches and it wasn't a surprise when I saw him three months ago and he ran over and gave me a hug when I hadn’t seen him for years.
quotes.quote_summary: Dan Gore was a raw, aggressive, and naturally talented forward at Burnley from a young age, always striving to win, while also demonstrating respect to coaches.
quotes.speaker: Lewis Craig

quotes.quote_raw: My last day working for Burnley, I had to deliver his review to his dad. Although he was a great striker, I didn’t think he scored poachers goals, like your Harry Kane or Ole Gunnar Solskjaer. He scored amazing goals and he was off the charts, but I thought he could be a better instinctive finisher. I remember his dad saying thank you because all he'd had for a couple of years was people telling him how good he was and nobody had said things to work on. He was prolific and he’d beat a few men and fire one into the top corner, but if someone wrapped a ball across the 18-yard box at speed, he probably didn’t have that instinctive finish in him every time. But he worked on it religiously. He always worked on stuff and he was in training early, even as a kid. I never pictured him as a midfielder because although his awareness was decent, it's different playing in that role. He’s developed his awareness now and when I see him driving the ball in midfield, it’s similar to how he played back then.
quotes.quote_summary: Despite Dan Gore's impressive goal-scoring record as a young striker at Burnley, I believed his finishing could be more instinctive, although he diligently worked on it. I never envisioned him as a midfielder but his awareness has developed significantly.
quotes.speaker: Lewis Craig

quotes.quote_raw: I worked with Danny at Burnley from Under-9s to Under-12s and I took that age group all the way through, so I worked with him for quite a while, and outside of Burnley with my own coaching. Some of the things I’ve seen him do for United, he’s been doing since back then. He’s dropped deeper now, but when he played up front for Burnley he'd score over 100 goals each season and I’m not even exaggerating. There was a game at Blackburn once when we built possession well, Dan picked the ball up inside his own half and he just started running past people and he ended up finishing it off, which was unbelievable. There was another time when he faced someone up, stopped the ball dead and did the Yannick Bolaise showboating thing when he bent down and flicked the grass, so he had a little bit of cheekiness about him. He was a matchwinner and they were a really good group. I always thought It was just a matter of time before United would come in for him and I always expected that. I can’t think of many times he didn't have a good day.
quotes.quote_summary: Even at a young age with Burnley, Dan exhibited the same skills he demonstrates now at United. He consistently scored over 100 goals a season, possessed exciting dribbling skills, and a cheeky confidence on the pitch. He was a natural match-winner.
quotes.speaker: Mike Hargreaves

quotes.quote_raw: His real stand-out qualities were he was hard-working, aggressive, he put himself about and he was a really exciting dribbler. He was fantastic with the ball and capable of sprinting repeatedly. His speed endurance was phenomenal, even at those ages. His attitude was great and he was demanding of his teammates and the standards of the session. Towards the end of Under-11s, we had a tournament on Blackpool’s pitch and it was a full-day affair. We played United in the final of that and Danny scored. They were just completely top draw that day as a group. I remember building up to that tournament for a few weeks and reiterating what we were building up to and you’d see a change in him, almost like a switch being flicked and a refocus. You could see he wanted to win.
quotes.quote_summary: Dan was always a hard worker, aggressive, and an exciting dribbler with remarkable speed and endurance. His attitude was excellent, demanding of both himself and his teammates. His drive to win was especially evident in the lead-up to and during a tournament final against United.
quotes.speaker: Mike Hargreaves

quotes.quote_raw: He’s captain material I'd say. Almost like your old-school Roy Keane type with hard challenges, but he’s got unbelievable quality on the ball because he was a forward in the past as well. In that Under-21 group at United, there have been the likes of Shola Shoretire and Isak Hasen-Aaroen but it seems like there's been something missing in them, which doesn’t seem to be the case with Dan. If you leave him in an environment long enough he thrives and I think it's fair to say that Dan wasn’t a Burnley type of player, in the sense that he was probably beyond Burnley in terms of his ability. He would have played for Burnley’s first-team if he was still there and Sean Dyche would have been all over him, but there was always an acceptance of Dan was Salford, Man United and there were murmurings going on in the background. Kids get poached in academies all the time, but I think Burnley got looked after with the deal when he did go over. And I think he was given certain guarantees because United knew the talent they were getting.
quotes.quote_summary: Dan has the qualities of a captain, reminiscent of Roy Keane's style. His abilities exceeded Burnley's environment and while he would likely have thrived there under Sean Dyche, his natural path seemed destined for Manchester United.
quotes.speaker: Lewis Craig

quotes.quote_raw: You can tell what Manchester United means to him when he plays. I went to the Youth Cup final and I just thought he was outstanding, doing the horrible side of the game really well. I thought out of possession, Dan was excellent, picking up second balls and showing all the stuff he's added to his game as a midfielder and you can see he's got a real understanding of the game now.
quotes.quote_summary: Dan's passion for Manchester United is evident in his play. His performance in the Youth Cup final was exceptional, particularly his work ethic and strategic understanding of the game as a midfielder.
quotes.speaker: Lewis Craig

quotes.quote_raw: I saw him right at the end when they were doing the lap of honour because I was sitting near the front, so I went down and shouted. He said 'aaaah Mike!' and I congratulated him, so it was nice to have that moment and I did have to laugh because near the end of the Youth Cup final, he was tapping his head and telling people to focus. That’s stuck with me because it’s something I do myself. We had great times at Burnley and he was the star of the group. I’ve got a great relationship with him and his dad, who was always very grateful for us looking after him.
quotes.quote_summary: It was great to see Dan after his Youth Cup final win, even reminding his teammates to stay focused near the end. He was always the standout player and his dad appreciated how he was cared for at Burnley.
quotes.speaker: Mike Hargreaves

quotes.quote_raw: You’re around top players every day at United and you either adapt or die. Even if he ends up making 100 appearances for United in the Premier League or with another club, he'll get the most out of himself. Ten Hag has been known for developing youngsters at Ajax and he doesn’t put people in who aren’t good enough. I'm really proud of him and it's lovely when you bump into him, or get a text.
quotes.quote_summary: At United, you must adapt to the high level of play. Dan will succeed regardless of where he ends up, and Ten Hag's trust in him speaks volumes about his talent. I'm incredibly proud of his achievements.
quotes.speaker: Lewis Craig

quotes.quote_raw: It’s been brilliant to see him progress and I’m a United fan myself, so I'm extremely pleased because it's more than he deserves. I genuinely think he embodies what a United player should be, bringing excitement, being hard-working and holding himself in the right way.
quotes.quote_summary: Dan's progression is fantastic, and as a United fan, I'm thrilled for him. His hard work, exciting play, and conduct embody what a United player represents.
quotes.speaker: Mike Hargreaves

quotes.quote_raw: I haven't focused on it yet, and I haven't heard anything from the club. Right now it's just about football, and then we have to see where we stand in January and for that matter in the summer.
quotes.quote_summary: I haven't thought about my future yet, and the club hasn't said anything.  I'm focused on playing right now, and we'll see what happens in January or the summer.
quotes.speaker: Christian Eriksen

quotes.quote_raw: To everyone at Manchester United Football Club, in particular the backroom staff, the players and the fans. I want to thank you from the bottom of my heart for your incredible efforts and support. It has been a privilege and honour to represent the club as a player, coach and manager, and I will always cherish the memories we have shared together. Man United will always have a special place in my heart, and I hope there are many more glory days at Old Trafford very soon - not only because I want the club to do well, but because you all deserve it! All the best and take care.
quotes.quote_summary: I want to thank everyone at Manchester United for their support. It's been an honor to represent the club, and I cherish the memories. I wish the club many more glory days.
quotes.speaker: Ruud van Nistelrooy

quotes.quote_raw: When [Manchester United](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/all-about/manchester-united-fc) talked to me, Omar, they told me about their plans. It's a real honour because I was the first choice to start that path. So it's a great responsibility. But you feel honoured and excited to be part of that. And we know that if the team plays well and wins games, everything looks so much better and the people really start to believe in the new stadium and new ideas.
quotes.quote_summary: I'm honored to be chosen to lead the club and its plans, and I'm excited about the renewed belief if we perform well and win.
quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim

quotes.quote_raw: I felt a connection [with Berrada, Ashworth and Wilcox] and I felt we are in the same moment. We want to do something special in the special club. So, I think that was a key point.
quotes.quote_summary: I feel a strong connection with Berrada, Ashworth, and Wilcox, and we share the same goal of achieving something special at this club.
quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim

quotes.quote_raw: I don't want to say that we need time because we are a young team. They are prepared. They are prepared to cope with the demands of playing for Manchester United. They should be because they are here. We know it will take time and we will try to win time with the games. But we have to start since day one without fear, without thinking that they are not used to playing like this.
quotes.quote_summary: Despite our young team, we don't need time.  They are ready to play for Manchester United. We must start without fear from day one.
quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim

quotes.quote_raw: I think you will see an idea. You could like it or not, I don't know, but you will see an idea. You will see a positioning. You will see something that we want to reach that kind of level. You will feel that. We have to know that it's like two trainings before the first match. This is the best league in the world. But if I have to say something to you, [it's that] you will see an idea. This I can guarantee.
quotes.quote_summary: You will see a clear tactical approach and style of play from my team.  Despite limited training time, I guarantee a defined vision for Manchester United in this league.
quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim

quotes.quote_raw: There are times when things don't go the way we want, but one thing is certain: the bond I have with you, dear fans, will remain unforgettable. You have given me so much, more than I can express in words, and I will always carry with me all the affection you have given me. You will always be in my heart. Good luck @juventus.
quotes.quote_summary: I may be leaving Juventus, but my connection with the fans will always be cherished. Thank you for everything.
quotes.speaker: Paul Pogba

quotes.quote_raw: Phenomenon as a player but even more phenomenal as a person you are [red heart emoji].
quotes.quote_summary: You're an amazing player, but an even better person.

quotes.quote_raw: Juventus Football Club and Paul Pogba announce that they have reached a mutual agreement for the termination of their contract as of 30 November, 2024. The club wishes Paul the very best for his professional future.
quotes.quote_summary: Juventus and Paul Pogba have mutually agreed to terminate his contract, effective November 30, 2024. We wish him well.
quotes.speaker: Juventus

quotes.quote_raw: I laugh, because it is Uncle Pat [Patrick Evra], he said it as a joke. I am still under contract, so it is not credible. I already have a club, so I [am] only thinking about returning and getting out of this situation. Of course, nobody knows what tomorrow holds, so never say never.
quotes.quote_summary: The Marseille rumors are a joke from Evra. I'm focused on my current club and returning to form, but never say never.
quotes.speaker: Paul Pogba

quotes.quote_raw: My main focus right now is just to get myself ready. I keep training and everything. Get ready for being able to join a team in January.
quotes.quote_summary: I'm concentrating on preparing myself to join a team in January.
quotes.speaker: Paul Pogba

quotes.quote_raw: With everyone fit, I'd like to see a back three of Leny Yoro, Matthijs de Ligt and Lisandro Martinez in front of Andre Onana. I'd like to see Bruno Fernandes and Kobbie Mainoo in the middle with Diogo Dalot and Noussair Mazraoui as wing-backs. Then Alejandro Garnacho and Marcus Rashford in behind Rasmus Hojlund. That team has plenty of creativity as well as pace at the back, but I’m sure everyone under Amorim will get a chance to impress.
quotes.quote_summary: My ideal starting XI under Amorim: Yoro, De Ligt, and Martinez in defense; Dalot and Mazraoui as wing-backs; Fernandes and Mainoo in midfield; Garnacho and Rashford behind Hojlund. This lineup offers creativity, pace, and I believe everyone will get a chance to shine.
quotes.speaker: Wes Brown

quotes.quote_raw: I think you will see an idea. You could like it or not, I don't know, but you will see an idea. You will see a positioning. You will see something that we want to reach that kind of level. You will feel that. We have to know that it's like two trainings before the first match. This is the best league in the world. But if I have to say something to you, [it's that] you will see an idea. This I can guarantee.
quotes.quote_summary: Despite having limited training time before our first match in this demanding league, you will see a clear tactical idea and our intended playing style.
quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim

quotes.quote_raw: A lot of people now talk about the 3-4-3 and the 4-3-3 and all that stuff. But when I think as a player or as a team-mate of [Manchester United], it is not a system or formation – it's like the character of the players, the way they see the club. So we have to focus on that before everything [in terms] of how we play, how we press. The most important thing for me, at this moment, is to create the principles, the identity and the character that we had in the past.
quotes.quote_summary: Tactical formations are secondary to the players' character and their connection with the club. Rebuilding the team's principles, identity, and past character is my priority.
quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim

quotes.quote_raw: To do it so late on and it means something, now we get the play-off in March, it's very important and I think it was what the performance deserved. I don't think anyone can argue that. I thought we dominated, I thought we played well. We got done by an unbelievable goal, from their perspective, but I think our performance deserved the win and I'm just happy to step up at the last minute to make sure that the lads got what we deserved.
quotes.quote_summary: Scoring so late to secure the March play-off was important and deserved, especially after conceding such an impressive goal from the other team.
quotes.speaker: Andy Robertson

quotes.quote_raw: First cap to 80th cap. Same stadium, same feeling! Proud to join the legend Darren Fletcher as third-most capped. The win was the cherry on top of the cake, see you all in March.
quotes.quote_summary: From my first cap to my 80th, it feels the same. Proud to equal Darren Fletcher's cap record, and winning topped it off.
quotes.speaker: Andy Robertson

quotes.quote_raw: Privilege
quotes.quote_summary: It's a privilege.
quotes.speaker: Bruno Fernandes

quotes.quote_raw: In the first stage, we made six changes from one game to the next. It’s important for us to be first – and we already are. We need to be competitive to add to the group, it’s getting harder and harder to get into the starting eleven. There’s a World Cup finals in 18 months. The game against Croatia is important, we need to look at other players. We’re going to let go of Bernardo Silva, Pedro Neto, Cristiano Ronaldo and Bruno Fernandes, who is suspended – so we’re going to call up Fabio Silva and [Geovany] Quenda from the Under-21s.
quotes.quote_summary: We rotated the squad heavily in the first stage.  Securing the top spot was key, and we've achieved that. Competition for places is intensifying with the World Cup approaching. The Croatia game allows us to assess other players. With some players unavailable, we'll bring in some U21s.
quotes.speaker: Roberto Martinez

quotes.quote_raw: Everyone agrees Old Trafford needs updating but the big question is how that is funded.
quotes.quote_summary: Old Trafford needs an update, but the question is how to fund it.
quotes.speaker: Manchester United Supporters Trust (MUST)

quotes.quote_raw: Other clubs have funded stadium work through debt, but due to the existing huge debt burden the Glazers have placed on United, that option is not open to us. This is an investment project so should be funded by capital, not ticket prices.
quotes.quote_summary: Other clubs use debt for stadium work, but the Glazers' debt prevents that for us. This project needs capital investment, not ticket price hikes.
quotes.speaker: Manchester United Supporters Trust (MUST)

quotes.quote_raw: We believe the owners should either invest themselves or issue new shares to allow others – including fans - to invest to make this happen. Stadium improvements should not be funded by big ticket increases on ordinary match-going Reds.
quotes.quote_summary: Owners should invest or issue shares to fund stadium improvements, not raise ticket prices for fans.
quotes.speaker: Manchester United Supporters Trust (MUST)
