quotes.quote_raw: It's obviously a big challenge, an incredible football club, obviously huge, and gig expectation. It's where you want to be in terms of testing yourselve against the best, he's there and I hope he does well. I'm obviously a supporter, my family are, and we love the club aswell so I really hope it works out. There's good players there, good people at the club, hopefully he goes there and settles really quickly.
quotes.quote_summary: Managing Manchester United is a huge challenge with high expectations, but I hope Amorim thrives. I'm a supporter and hope it works out for him.
quotes.speaker: Michael Carrick

quotes.quote_raw: Our opening game of the season was Liverpool at home. We thought that was big. We then went away to Man City in the second game. We thought that was big. This is going to be huge. The eyes of the world are upon us on and off the pitch. It's a chance for us to be the best version of ourselves and show Ipswich as a club, a town and a community to the world. That's the platform that the Premier League gives you. I'm also buzzing for Kieran [McKenna] to be given the opportunity to pit his wits against his former club.
quotes.quote_summary: Playing against Liverpool and Man City were big, but facing Man United will be huge, with global attention. It's a chance for Ipswich to showcase ourselves to the world. I'm thrilled for Kieran McKenna to face his old club.
quotes.speaker: Mark Ashton

quotes.quote_raw: I think Manchester United will keep looking at that centre-forward position as an area they can strengthen. We’ll see whether that’s a position Ruben Amorim will be able to address in January and whether he’ll be able to bring Viktor Gyökeres from Sporting in with him in the near future. He’s certainly enjoyed scoring a lot of goals in Portugal and for Coventry over the past couple of years and Manchester United have been waiting to have a natural goalscorer up front for a few years now, so he fits the bill in that respect.
quotes.quote_summary: Man United needs a stronger centre-forward, and Gyökeres' goal-scoring record makes him a suitable candidate.
quotes.speaker: Gary Pallister

quotes.quote_raw: It’s not really up to me when my contract runs out, it’s up to the club. When the summer comes if the offer is there I will definitely take it seriously.
quotes.quote_summary: Contract renewal is the club's decision, but I'll consider any offer seriously in the summer.
quotes.speaker: Christian Eriksen

quotes.quote_raw: It's very sad that he's leaving, but of course we understand his decision. He has of course meant a lot, considering that he gave me that chance and that he made me develop so much.
quotes.quote_summary: While I'm sad about his departure, I understand his reasons and am grateful for the opportunity and growth he provided me.
quotes.speaker: Viktor Gyokeres

quotes.quote_raw: He [Amorim] probably has some strikers there already, so we'll see. He hasn't [contacted me], it's fun but nothing I attach any importance to because it's talk and nothing concrete.
quotes.quote_summary: I'm aware of the rumors about Amorim wanting me at United, but they are unsubstantiated at this point.
quotes.speaker: Viktor Gyokeres

quotes.quote_raw: He's had times where he's struggled, but I think this season he's been absolutely brilliant, overall. He absolutely deserves a new contract. Manchester United can't afford to rest on their laurels. He's a winger worth more than €40million (£33.4m). I love the way he receives the ball, is calm, his awareness of his surroundings and, of course, the big goals and chances he creates. He can be Ruben Amorim's Bukayo Saka.
quotes.quote_summary: Amad has been brilliant this season, deserves a new contract, and is a valuable player. His composure, awareness, and goal contributions are impressive. He has the potential to be Amorim's Saka.
quotes.speaker: Seydou Doumbia

quotes.quote_raw: I think it's a no-brainer that Man United will give him a new contract. Every time he was given a chance, he always showed his goal. I think it will be even better with Amorim.
quotes.quote_summary: Giving Amad a new contract is obvious. He always delivers and will improve further under Amorim.
quotes.speaker: Emmanuel Eboue

quotes.quote_raw: For both Frenkie and Virgil it is better for them to leave the training camp at this moment. That decision was taken on medical grounds, with of course the interest of the players coming first.
quotes.quote_summary: Frenkie and Virgil's departure from training camp is in their best medical interest.
quotes.speaker: Ronald Koeman

quotes.quote_raw: We've had a couple of boys in this week from Man United. They've been training with us and that's been really good, just to have a look at them. We also sent two to Man United.
quotes.quote_summary: We've had a couple of Man United boys training with us this week, which has been beneficial. We also sent two of our players to them.
quotes.speaker: Grant McCann

quotes.quote_raw: It's about forming a relationship with them which is great and there's other clubs that want to do that as well and that speaks volumes about how we're playing and performing.
quotes.quote_summary: Building a relationship with Man United is great, and other clubs wanting the same shows how well we're doing.
quotes.speaker: Grant McCann

quotes.quote_raw: It's really good to have a chance to look at things like this. They're two of Man United's better U21 players and they both played in the game [behind-closed-doors] and were both excellent.
quotes.quote_summary: It's good to have this opportunity. The two Man United U21 players were excellent in the behind-closed-doors game.
quotes.speaker: Grant McCann

quotes.quote_raw: One's a wide player [Sharpe] and the other is a midfielder [McAllister].Travis [Binnion] has been brilliant with us and the fact we've managed to get Kasper and Sam in there is great, to show them what a Premier League club looks like but also to see they work and train and deliver sessions.
quotes.quote_summary: Sharpe is a wide player, McAllister a midfielder. Binnion has been great and it's good for our players to experience a Premier League club.
quotes.speaker: Grant McCann

quotes.quote_raw: It's been a worthwhile week and having that link with one of the biggest clubs in the world is huge. If you're a young player at Man United then you've got everything there. They have the best training ground, the best pitches, best food. Everything is just laid on for you.
quotes.quote_summary: This week's link with Man United has been invaluable. Young players there have everything provided for them.
quotes.speaker: Grant McCann

quotes.quote_raw: I remember when they came to us [EFL Trophy group game] wearing brand new Hugo Boss suits. We're in our tracksuits, so it's just a different world. But coming here gives them an insight into what it means to win three points as opposed to U21 football where it doesn't really matter. It's a huge thing.
quotes.quote_summary: Man United's players arrived in Hugo Boss suits, highlighting the different worlds. But training here shows them the importance of winning, unlike in U21 football.
quotes.speaker: Grant McCann

quotes.quote_raw: Delighted to get both U16 and U18 goal of the season. More to come next season..
quotes.quote_summary: Very happy to have won Goal of the Season for both U16 and U18, and I'm looking forward to achieving more next season.
quotes.speaker: Jim Thwaites

quotes.quote_raw: Good first session with the first team.
quotes.quote_summary: I had a good first training session with the main team.
quotes.speaker: Jim Thwaites

quotes.quote_raw: We didn’t expect the case of Lisandro. We saw that he had suffered a blow to his back, but apparently, he had no problem, just pain. When he arrived here, the pain increased a bit, he underwent tests and is not fit to be here.
quotes.quote_summary: Lisandro's back injury was unexpected. He initially had pain, but tests showed he's unfit to play.
quotes.speaker: Lionel Scaloni

quotes.quote_raw: It’s very sad. He just come back from injury and then to get another injury, you suffer with that. It was tough to see. He was very down in the dressing room too. He’s an important man in the team, he’s captain anyway. No, it was a shame. I gave him a hug and told him to get well.
quotes.quote_summary: It's sad that Lindelof got injured again right after returning. He's important to the team and was very upset. I offered my support.
quotes.speaker: Emil Holm

quotes.quote_raw: Harry [Maguire] is still working inside on his rehabilitation.
quotes.quote_summary: Harry Maguire is still working on his rehabilitation.
quotes.speaker: Ruud van Nistelrooy

quotes.quote_raw: So, from day one, we will start with our identity. The most important thing for me at this moment is to create the principles, the identity and the character that we had in the past.
quotes.quote_summary: We'll begin by establishing our identity, focusing on recreating the principles, identity, and character of the past.
quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim

quotes.quote_raw: If you work as a team, then the talent individually is going to shine.
quotes.quote_summary: Individual talent flourishes when working effectively as a team.
quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim

quotes.quote_raw: That feeling when you are living rent free in people's heads
quotes.quote_summary: I'm living rent free in their heads!
quotes.speaker: Rebekah Vardy

quotes.quote_raw: [Responding to Coleen Rooney sinking twice] the gift that keeps on giving
quotes.quote_summary: Coleen sinking is hilarious!
quotes.speaker: Rebekah Vardy

quotes.quote_raw: Everyone thinks Jamie is mad at me for speaking out, but that couldn’t be further from the truth. He’s encouraging me, saying, ‘Give it to her, get the truth out there’. He loves it that she’s back getting headlines. The more stick he gets from the stands in football, the better he plays.
quotes.quote_summary: Jamie isn't mad, he actually encourages me to speak out against Coleen and loves the attention. He even plays better when fans taunt him.
quotes.speaker: Rebekah Vardy

quotes.quote_raw: Give it to her, get the truth out there
quotes.quote_summary: Go Rebekah, expose the truth!
quotes.speaker: Jamie Vardy

quotes.quote_raw: It’s no secret that he will probably move to Liverpool next summer. I would put a few euros on it. As the successor to his great idol Mo Salah. Things couldn’t get any better for him.
quotes.quote_summary: Omar Marmoush is likely to join Liverpool next summer, possibly as Salah's successor.
quotes.speaker: Marcel Reif

quotes.quote_raw: That [amount] won't be enough. It's often the case with many players who join us that we provide them with an environment where they can continue to develop—fully aware that we would let them go if they develop faster than the club itself. That's an agreement we make with the players.
quotes.quote_summary: €40m won't be enough for Marmoush. We help players develop and let them go if they outgrow the club.
quotes.speaker: Markus Krosche

quotes.quote_raw: I would say Dele (Alli). My first few camps, when I was younger, and he was at the top of his game at that time.
quotes.quote_summary: Dele Alli was my toughest opponent in training, especially during my early days when he was at his peak.
quotes.speaker: Trent Alexander-Arnold

quotes.quote_raw: He was untouchable.
quotes.quote_summary: He was untouchable.
quotes.speaker: Trent Alexander-Arnold

quotes.quote_raw: I spoke about it in my interview and don't want to go over it too much again – but I know my level as a player and what I can get to. It's hard for me to even watch football. It's been tough for me, I'd say, this past eight months has been hard to watch.
quotes.quote_summary: I know my potential as a player, and though it's been tough, the past eight months have been challenging.
quotes.speaker: Dele Alli

quotes.quote_raw: You know you can set reminders on your phone, I have a reminder at 11 o'clock every day that says, 'World Cup 2026'. That's my aim for now. I think that people will be like, 'he hasn't played in a year,' but I don't care, I know my level.
quotes.quote_summary: I have daily reminders about the 2026 World Cup, which is my current goal, regardless of my playing time this year.
quotes.speaker: Dele Alli

quotes.quote_raw: [He] likes to play games with the opposition. I’ve seen him tell injured players to come on the team bus and walk into the dressing room with their wash bag to put the other manager off the scent.
quotes.quote_summary: Arteta tries to mislead the opposition by having injured players appear as if they are fit.
quotes.speaker: Oleksandr Zinchenko

quotes.quote_raw: He’s not fit’
quotes.quote_summary: If a player isn't fit, I'll say so.
quotes.speaker: Mikel Arteta

quotes.quote_raw: do their homework
quotes.quote_summary: Opponents should prepare thoroughly before facing us.
quotes.speaker: Mikel Arteta

quotes.quote_raw: My formation would be 3-2-1 because it's the one that I think works better for the King's league format. I would choose Iker Casillas in goal. The three in the back I would say [Carlos] Puyol, Rio Ferdinand and myself. Then in the midfield I would say [Andres] Iniesta and Cesc Fabregas. Up front, Leo Messi
quotes.quote_summary: My ideal seven-a-side formation is 3-2-1 with Casillas, Puyol, Ferdinand, myself, Iniesta, Fabregas, and Messi.
quotes.speaker: Gerard Pique

quotes.quote_raw: I have to choose one striker Leo and Cristiano, I decide for Leo.
quotes.quote_summary: Between Messi and Ronaldo, I choose Messi for striker.
quotes.speaker: Gerard Pique

quotes.quote_raw: Ferdinand and Puyol been important for me in a personal way. I was really young when I joined Manchester United, and Rio helped me with that. Also when I joined Barcelona, I was 21, and Puyol was captain, and he also helped me a lot to start my career. Those two have been two incredible centre-backs.
quotes.quote_summary: Ferdinand and Puyol were crucial in my early career, both offering invaluable support at Manchester United and Barcelona, respectively.
quotes.speaker: Gerard Pique

quotes.quote_raw: I'll say Cesc Fabregas because he's like a brother, and, I think, in the Premier League, he's been one of the greatest; his first year at Arsenal was incredible. I would also say Iniesta because he won us the World Cup, and the goal is more than enough, but the quality he had is just amazing.
quotes.quote_summary: I'd pick Fabregas, who's like a brother and a Premier League great, and Iniesta, for his World Cup-winning goal and overall amazing quality.
quotes.speaker: Gerard Pique

quotes.quote_raw: Every briefing coming out of OT [Old Trafford] underlines what a cataclysmic mistake it was keeping [Erik] ten Toast [Hag] last summer. They let him spend another £200m+ on rubbish & now there’s nothing for Amorim. Somebody in the brains trust should be fired. There’s nothing for Amorim to work with.
quotes.quote_summary: Keeping Ten Hag last summer was a huge mistake. He wasted over £200m on poor signings, leaving Amorim with no budget. Someone should be held accountable.
quotes.speaker: Richard Keys

quotes.quote_raw: Liverpool were s***.
quotes.quote_summary: Liverpool were bad.
quotes.speaker: David Coote

quotes.quote_raw: A c***. Absolute c***. Aside from having a right pop at me when I refereed them against Burnley in lockdown, then he accused me of lying and then just had a right f***ing pop at me. I've got no interest in speaking to somebody who's f***ing arrogant.
quotes.quote_summary: Jurgen Klopp is an arrogant person who criticized and accused me of lying. I don't want to communicate with him.
quotes.speaker: David Coote

quotes.quote_raw: David Coote has been suspended with immediate effect pending a full investigation. PGMOL will be making no further comment until that process is complete.
quotes.quote_summary: David Coote has been suspended pending investigation. No further comment.
quotes.speaker: PGMOL

quotes.quote_raw: He’s done something stupid, you can imagine what the fella’s going through. I don’t want that, talking about cancel culture, but my point being is how could he then – he could never referee a Liverpool game, but how could he then do a rival?
quotes.quote_summary: Coote's actions were foolish, and while I don't support cancel culture, his comments make it hard for him to referee Liverpool or their rivals.
quotes.speaker: Jamie Carragher

quotes.quote_raw: The thing I despise most about social media is not people giving me stick, it’s when a referee makes a decision and that whole fan base is like ‘the world’s against us’. My own fan base are like that, but whoever it is, I can’t get into my head that a referee’s like that because you’d never sleep. I just think because of what he said about Liverpool, I think it’s make it difficult. I don’t want to see anyone cancelled.
quotes.quote_summary: I hate how fans on social media react to referee decisions, claiming bias. I can't imagine a referee being intentionally biased. Coote's comments complicate things, but I don't want him cancelled.
quotes.speaker: Jamie Carragher

quotes.quote_raw: I made it clear in the last few years that I want to go somewhere and be a number one. The club has made that decision to get a goalkeeper (Mamardashvili) which makes it look like they’ve made a decision to go another direction. Liverpool have rejected a few bids as well. It’s not always in my hands to fully make the decision. My ambition is clear. I’m good enough & I want to go and play week in, week out.
quotes.quote_summary: I've always wanted to be a starting goalkeeper, and Liverpool's decision to sign another goalkeeper suggests they're going in a different direction.  Although they've rejected bids for me, my goal remains to play regularly.
quotes.speaker: Caoimhin Kelleher

quotes.quote_raw: You could like it or not, I don’t know, but you will see an idea [against Ipswich]. You will see a positioning. You will see something that we want to reach… that kind of level. You will feel that.
quotes.quote_summary: Against Ipswich, regardless of your opinion, you'll see my team's developing game plan and target level.
quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim

quotes.quote_raw: We have to know that it’s like two trainings before the first match. This is the best league in the world. But if I have to say something to you, [it’s that] you will see an idea. This I can guarantee.
quotes.quote_summary: Despite limited training before the match in this demanding league, I guarantee you'll see my team's strategic approach.
quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim

quotes.quote_raw: We know that we need time, but we have to win time. To win time is to win games. But the most important thing for me is identity. So since day one we will start with our identity. Of course we are going to prepare the games, but we will focus a lot in our game model. How to play, how to press, these small things, small details. You cannot go 100% on every detail because it will be confusing for the players. If I have to say one thing, my main goal, my first goal, is identity.
quotes.quote_summary: Winning requires establishing our identity. From the start, we focus on our game model, how we play and press. Too much detail can be confusing, so establishing our identity is the primary goal.
quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim

quotes.quote_raw: Can you beat a quiz by The Menace? This time it's a football quiz and it's on the Premier League in the 2020s. I bet you won't get all five!
quotes.quote_summary: Think you can beat my Premier League quiz on the 2020s? I bet you won't get all five right!
quotes.speaker: Darragh Ennis

quotes.quote_raw: So, how did that go? Are you like Rodri or more of a plonker like Rodney Trotter?
quotes.quote_summary: So, how'd you do? Are you a Premier League pro like Rodri, or more like Rodney Trotter?
quotes.speaker: Darragh Ennis

quotes.quote_raw: 4/5- thought City might have been the team to make profit.
quotes.quote_summary: I got 4 out of 5 right. I thought Man City would have made a profit.
quotes.speaker: One fan

quotes.quote_raw: 4/5 went with Brentford for net profit
quotes.quote_summary: I got 4/5 right, I guessed Brentford for net profit.
quotes.speaker: Another commented

quotes.quote_raw: They might well soon. I think big offers will come in for a few of their players in the summer.
quotes.quote_summary: Brentford might actually soon be in profit. I anticipate significant offers for some of their players in the coming summer transfer window.
quotes.speaker: Darragh Ennis

quotes.quote_raw: 4/5. Went for Brentford over Brighton. Silly in hindsight.
quotes.quote_summary: I got 4/5. Chose Brentford over Brighton, which seems silly now.
quotes.speaker: A third fan added

quotes.quote_raw: 4/5 thought Liverpool was net positive but I guess last season changed that…
quotes.quote_summary: Got 4/5. Assumed Liverpool was net positive, but I guess last season's spending changed things.
quotes.speaker: Someone else wrote

quotes.quote_raw: 4/5 - Went Wolves instead of Brighton.
quotes.quote_summary: 4 out of 5 right. I picked Wolves for net profit, not Brighton.
quotes.speaker: A fifth said

quotes.quote_raw: I was worried before and during the match. I’m not worried anymore now. Endrick had courage in that last ball of the match. The best solution was to take advantage of the three against one, but he was convinced. He did it very well. It was the most complicated solution, but it worked out very well for him. He is capable of doing things that no one can think of. At least, I didn't think of that. He has the gift of being very effective. You can see that he has something special. And a very strong and very fast shot.
quotes.quote_summary: I was initially worried about Endrick's performance, but his courageous play and effective finishing impressed me. He has a special talent and a powerful shot.
quotes.speaker: Carlo Ancelotti

quotes.quote_raw: focused on daily work until his opportunity arrives
quotes.quote_summary: I'm concentrating on training every day and waiting for my chance.
quotes.speaker: Endrick

quotes.quote_raw: It has been a privilege to pull on the shirt of the Bianconeri and to share so many special moments together. I cherish the memories we made. They live on. Even in the most difficult moments over the past year, your support was crucial and I want to thank Juve fans around the world for their compassion. I am looking forward to the next chapter of my career and to stepping out on the pitch with my next club.
quotes.quote_summary: Playing for Juventus was an honor, with cherished memories. Fan support was vital during tough times. I'm excited for the next stage in my career.
quotes.speaker: Paul Pogba

quotes.quote_raw: Playing for Arsenal is still a huge part of my career. Playing with The Gunners, it’s unforgettable. I won titles [the FA Cup and the Community Shield] with this great club, so it was far from a bad experience. I still remember the good things. The Arsenal chapter, I won’t say it’s behind me. It’s, above all, something I’ll carry with me until the end of my career.
quotes.quote_summary: My time at Arsenal, including winning the FA Cup and Community Shield, remains a significant and positive part of my career.
quotes.speaker: Nicolas Pepe

quotes.quote_raw: At the time, I had a discussion with Unai Emery that lasted almost an hour. He explained to me how he wanted me to fit into the team, and obviously, it convinced me.
quotes.quote_summary: Unai Emery's hour-long discussion about my role in the team convinced me to join.
quotes.speaker: Nicolas Pepe

quotes.quote_raw: Honestly, I’ve turned the page. I have no rancour. Frankly, I wish Mikel Arteta the best.
quotes.quote_summary: I've moved on from Arsenal without resentment and wish Arteta well.
quotes.speaker: Nicolas Pepe

quotes.quote_raw: I give them [the medals] to my mum.
quotes.quote_summary: I gave my medals to my mother.
quotes.speaker: Cole Palmer

quotes.quote_raw: I wanted to restock.
quotes.quote_summary: I wanted to make room for more awards.
quotes.speaker: Cole Palmer

quotes.quote_raw: Clear them out so I can stock up again.
quotes.quote_summary: I'm clearing out space for new silverware.
quotes.speaker: Cole Palmer

quotes.quote_raw: The feeling you get when you win… you just want it again. You don’t want to stop and never get that feeling again.
quotes.quote_summary: Winning is such a great feeling that I want to experience it again and again.
quotes.speaker: Cole Palmer

quotes.quote_raw: We know that we need time, but we have to win time. To win time is to win games. But the most important thing for me is identity. So since day one we will start with our identity. Of course we are going to prepare the games, but we will focus a lot in our game model. How to play, how to press, these small things, small details. You cannot go 100% on every detail because it will be confusing for the players. So if I have to say one thing, my main goal, my first goal, is identity.
quotes.quote_summary: We need time to rebuild, and winning games buys us that time. However, establishing a clear team identity is my top priority from the start.
quotes.speaker: Rúben Amorim

quotes.quote_raw: That’s for sure. That’s why we are Manchester United. That’s why we are … a long time ago, we don’t win the Premier League. But if you ask, Manchester United is the biggest club in England. So this is part of the history, it is not now. So we have to address that, to show that and to try to win again.
quotes.quote_summary: Manchester United's history as England's biggest club is undeniable, but it's in the past. We must acknowledge it, but our focus is on reclaiming our winning ways.
quotes.speaker: Rúben Amorim

quotes.quote_raw: When Manchester United talked to me, Omar, they told me about their plans and you get excited. It’s a real honour because I was the first choice to start that path. So it’s a great responsibility. But you feel honoured and excited to be part of that. And we know that if the team plays well and wins games, ­everything looks so much better and the people really start to believe in the new stadium and new ideas. So, we know that we are the engine of the football. Manchester United is the engine of the Premier League in my opinion.
quotes.quote_summary: I was excited by the club's plans. Being their first choice is an honor and a responsibility. Our performance will drive belief in the new stadium and ideas. Manchester United drives the Premier League.
quotes.speaker: Rúben Amorim

quotes.quote_raw: It’s hard to explain. It’s strange because it’s a feeling of belonging at the first day. And I know that it’s going to be tough. I know it’s a massive ­challenge, but I feel quite relaxed. I feel at home and I think that is important in the beginning. So, I’m very excited.
quotes.quote_summary: It's a strange feeling of belonging from day one, despite knowing the tough challenge ahead. I feel at home and excited.
quotes.speaker: Rúben Amorim

quotes.quote_raw: To everyone at Manchester United Football Club, in particular the ­backroom staff, the players and the fans. I want to thank you from the bottom of my heart for your incredible efforts and support. It has been a privilege and honour to ­represent the club as a player, coach and manager, and I will always cherish the memories we have shared together. @ManUtd will always have a special place in my heart, and I hope there are many more glory days at Old Trafford very soon – not only because I want the club to do well, but because you all deserve it!
quotes.quote_summary: Thank you to everyone at Manchester United for your efforts and support. It's been a privilege to represent the club, and I cherish our shared memories. I hope for more glory days at Old Trafford soon, you deserve it.
quotes.speaker: Ruud van Nistelrooy

final_quotes.speaker: Andros Townsend
final_quotes.quote_raw: I don't think he will fully be able to get his methodologies across because some of the players don't come back from international duty until late in the week. I also don’t think Erik ten Hag was that far from getting things right - in terms of on the pitch - so I don’t think it’s wholesale changes.
final_quotes.quote_summary: The new manager might struggle initially due to players returning late from international duty. Ten Hag had almost got things right on the pitch, so no major changes are needed.

final_quotes.speaker: Andros Townsend
final_quotes.quote_raw: There are times this season when I have watched them and they have almost been there in terms of their performance. They would play well and create chances but they didn't have Rasmus Hojlund fit or any other number nine to put those chances away.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Man Utd's performance has been nearly there this season; they created chances but lacked a fit striker to finish them.

final_quotes.speaker: Andros Townsend
final_quotes.quote_raw: Ten Hag's philosophy was to press high but the likes of Garnacho have been injured and Mason Mount has hardly been available during his reign. He was unfortunate that he didn't have the players that he spent big money on available to implement his philosophy to the fullest.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Ten Hag's high-pressing philosophy was hampered by injuries and unavailability of key players like Garnacho and Mount.

final_quotes.speaker: Andros Townsend
final_quotes.quote_raw: It is just minor tweaks, so it is not going to take a million years for him to get the team he wants and the way he wants to play.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Only minor adjustments are needed, so the manager should quickly get the team playing as he desires.

final_quotes.speaker: Andros Townsend
final_quotes.quote_raw: Amorin’s biggest problem from now until Christmas is going to be time on the training pitch.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Amorim's main challenge until Christmas will be limited training time.

final_quotes.speaker: Chris Sutton
final_quotes.quote_raw: I still think there needs to be massive patience for Amorim. He needs a lot of time.
final_quotes.quote_summary: People need to be very patient with Amorim; he requires significant time.

final_quotes.speaker: Chris Sutton
final_quotes.quote_raw: In terms of expectations for this season - I don’t think they’re a team that is capable of finishing in a Champions League spot.
final_quotes.quote_summary: I don't believe they can secure a Champions League spot this season.

final_quotes.speaker: Joe McGrath
final_quotes.quote_raw: I think there are going to be teething issues at first and this season will still be a bit of a struggle. That is based on what we have seen at Sporting Lisbon and how strong he is in his principles of how he wants to play the game.
final_quotes.quote_summary: I anticipate initial struggles this season based on Amorim's time at Sporting and his firm principles.

final_quotes.speaker: Joe McGrath
final_quotes.quote_raw: Hopefully, we can still do something in a cup, but I think we will finish sixth in the league. I expect towards the end of this campaign to see us start to click.
final_quotes.quote_summary: We might achieve something in a cup competition, but I predict a sixth-place league finish, improving towards the end of the season.

final_quotes.speaker: Joe McGrath
final_quotes.quote_raw: I also expect there to be stars for this team that come out of nowhere but fit his style and formation. It might be players we have not rated in the past but step it up under him.
final_quotes.quote_summary: I expect some unexpected players will emerge as stars under Amorim, those who suit his style.

final_quotes.speaker: David Moyes
final_quotes.quote_raw: It is a huge privilege to be given the chance to manage Manchester United. There are only a few people who ever get the opportunity to manage at that level.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Managing Manchester United is a huge privilege and a rare opportunity.

final_quotes.speaker: David Moyes
final_quotes.quote_raw: I haven't managed at Real Madrid but, for me, Manchester United is a club which has bigger support worldwide. Every newspaper in the world would have been covering this story, because there are so many Manchester United supporters worldwide.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Manchester United has a larger global fanbase than even Real Madrid, making it a significant job.

final_quotes.speaker: David Moyes
final_quotes.quote_raw: So it is an incredible job, but it is different as well. I have to say that it carries a lot of pressure and an awful lot of media coverage. They are always looking for things on Manchester United.
final_quotes.quote_summary: It's an incredible but demanding job, with intense pressure and media scrutiny.

final_quotes.speaker: David Moyes
final_quotes.quote_raw: It might take a little bit of time for him to settle in but, if he gets given the time by the board, his statistics and what he's doing at the moment shows up very well in Portugal.
final_quotes.quote_summary: He might need time to adjust, but his track record in Portugal is excellent.

final_quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim
final_quotes.quote_raw: The most important thing for me at this moment is to create the principles, the identity and the character we had in the past. We will focus a lot on our game model - how to play, how to press, these small things. You cannot go 100% on every detail because it will be confusing for the players. But if I have to say one thing, my main goal, my first goal, it is identity.
final_quotes.quote_summary: My priority is establishing the principles, identity, and character we previously had, focusing on our game model, especially how we play and press.  Building an identity is my primary goal.

final_quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim
final_quotes.quote_raw: We want to do something special in a special club - that was a key point. When Manchester United told me about their plans, you get excited. We know if the team plays well and wins games, everything looks so much better and the people really start to believe in the new stadium and new ideas.
final_quotes.quote_summary: We aim to achieve something special at this club. United's plans are exciting. Success will build belief in the new stadium and ideas.

final_quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim
final_quotes.quote_raw: It's a real honour that I was the first choice to start that path.
final_quotes.quote_summary: I'm honored to be the chosen one to lead this journey.

final_quotes.speaker: Fara Williams
final_quotes.quote_raw: There has been some pressure on players carrying an injury going into international breaks with their national side because you are contracted to these clubs and that is where your income is. But, for me, as a player I had a similar [mindset to Harry Kane](https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/articles/cp8x4rvne86o) that I would always be available - injured or not injured. I would have injections when I was on international duty just so I could represent my country because it meant that much.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Despite pressure from clubs, playing for my country was paramount, even if injured. I'd take injections to represent my nation.

final_quotes.speaker: Fara Williams
final_quotes.quote_raw: It is difficult, however. If you look at Jack Grealish and [Pep Guardiola's comments,] he has a point because the forward has not been able to play for Manchester City because of injuries. So if you have been sidelined for three or four games, I would agree that you are then not fit and available to go on international duty.
final_quotes.quote_summary: It's a complex issue.  Guardiola is right to be concerned about Grealish; players sidelined for multiple games shouldn't be on international duty.

final_quotes.speaker: Fara Williams
final_quotes.quote_raw: But when you look at some of the other players, ones who have been playing and being managed by their club, then I do not see it being different to being played and managed by your country.
final_quotes.quote_summary: If players are playing for their club, I see no difference in playing for their country.

final_quotes.speaker: Fara Williams
final_quotes.quote_raw: From the club's side, when they are competing at such high levels in the Premier League, you can understand why they would want their players to be rested and get fully fit again over the two weeks, rather than having to come back straight into a hectic period of fixtures.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Clubs want their players rested during international breaks, especially given the Premier League's intensity.

final_quotes.speaker: Fara Williams
final_quotes.quote_raw: I kind of get it from both points of view but, as a player, if I am half fit and being played by my club, I would be fully available for my national team.
final_quotes.quote_summary: I understand both perspectives, but as a player, I'd always prioritize my national team.

final_quotes.speaker: Fara Williams
final_quotes.quote_raw: It is really difficult with the pressure that is on the players, though. I would not look at it as a decision players have made solely.
final_quotes.quote_summary: The pressure on players is immense regarding international duty; it's not solely their decision.

final_quotes.speaker: Jeorge Bird
final_quotes.quote_raw: There was a lot of speculation about his future. Arsenal reportedly offered him a scholarship contract and a professional deal, but I think he just decided that Manchester United is a better opportunity in terms of his development.
final_quotes.quote_summary: There was much speculation about Obi-Martin's future. Arsenal offered contracts, but he felt Manchester United was better for his development.

final_quotes.speaker: Jeorge Bird
final_quotes.quote_raw: The situation went on for quite a long time but now he has finally signed for United and is playing really well. It could prove to be a good decision for him in the end.
final_quotes.quote_summary: After a long period of uncertainty, he signed for United, where he's playing well. It seems to be a positive move for him.

final_quotes.speaker: Jeorge Bird
final_quotes.quote_raw: Very. But they might have to be a little bit patient as well.
final_quotes.quote_summary: United fans should be very excited but patient.

final_quotes.speaker: Jeorge Bird
final_quotes.quote_raw: He needs to play more for the under-21s first. If he played about 10 games at that level, then he might be ready for the first team.
final_quotes.quote_summary: He needs more experience with the under-21s, around 10 games, before he's ready for the first team.

final_quotes.speaker: Jeorge Bird
final_quotes.quote_raw: Even right now, he could do well as a substitute in cup games, but they will have to show a little bit of patience with him. Next season is more likely to be the time when he is pushing for first-team involvement, but he definitely has a lot of potential.
final_quotes.quote_summary: He could potentially be a substitute in cup games, but next season is more realistic for first-team involvement. He has a lot of potential.

final_quotes.speaker: Jeorge Bird
final_quotes.quote_raw: He is a really talented player. I watched him quite a few times for the Arsenal academy teams last season and he scored 32 goals for the under-18s, which was a record at that level for the club.
final_quotes.quote_summary: He's a very talented player. He broke Arsenal's under-18 scoring record with 32 goals last season.

final_quotes.speaker: Jeorge Bird
final_quotes.quote_raw: It is outrageous to score that many goals at that level. You normally get one or two players every few years who score quite a few goals, but no-one normally scores that many.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Scoring that many goals at youth level is remarkable. Very few players achieve such high numbers.

final_quotes.speaker: Jeorge Bird
final_quotes.quote_raw: At the beginning of the season he wasn't actually scoring that many goals but he just suddenly started to score and was playing with a lot of confidence. The way the Arsenal team played last season really suited how he played, which helps, but he just got into the right positions all the time. He knew where to run and was playing with so much confidence.
final_quotes.quote_summary: His scoring picked up significantly mid-season. Arsenal's style suited him, but his positioning and confidence were key.

final_quotes.speaker: Jeorge Bird
final_quotes.quote_raw: This season, Arsenal have found it a bit difficult without him and that shows how well he did.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Arsenal have struggled without him, demonstrating his value.

final_quotes.speaker: Jeorge Bird
final_quotes.quote_raw: Some people say he has a major advantage to those around him because he is so tall compared with other players at that level. It will be interesting to see when he plays against senior players whether he can still be as prolific, but he has really good qualities.
final_quotes.quote_summary: His height is advantageous at youth level. It remains to be seen if he maintains his prolific scoring against senior players, but he has excellent attributes.

final_quotes.speaker: Jeorge Bird
final_quotes.quote_raw: He can control the ball really well, he is quite quick and can get into good spaces. He is going to be a really good player but it will interesting to see how he does at a higher level.
final_quotes.quote_summary: He has good ball control, speed, and positioning. He'll be a great player, but his performance at a higher level remains to be seen.

final_quotes.speaker: Fara Williams
final_quotes.quote_raw: If Ruben Amorim had gone straight into Manchester United off the back of Erik ten Hag's sacking, I would have given him different priorities on his to-do list than what he has now. After Ruud van Nistelrooy's four games in charge, it is a different conversation with the players. Their confidence is already higher - you can see that in the performances - and that would have been something he would have looked at early on.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Amorim's priorities would be different had he taken over directly after Ten Hag.  Van Nistelrooy boosted player confidence, which is a key change.

final_quotes.speaker: Fara Williams
final_quotes.quote_raw: One of his first priorities now will be getting to know the players. When a manager first comes in, you can change who you are as a player a little bit in those first few weeks. You want to impress and players and managers are working each other out. But he will know the ones trying to pull the wool over his eyes and the players will know that with him. You must build those relationships early.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Getting to know the players is crucial.  Players try to impress new managers, but Amorim will see through any facades. Building relationships early is essential.

final_quotes.speaker: Fara Williams
final_quotes.quote_raw: Amorim needs to identify the areas of development that these players need, individually and collectively. Have those conversations and find out how players are feeling given the pressure they have been under with results.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Amorim must identify areas for player development, both individual and collective, and understand how they're coping with the pressure.

final_quotes.speaker: Fara Williams
final_quotes.quote_raw: However, trying to understand players in a short space of time is difficult and he will be learning about them on the job.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Quickly understanding players is tough; Amorim will learn on the job.

final_quotes.speaker: Fara Williams
final_quotes.quote_raw: The international break provides an added challenge, particularly with the style of play Amorim has. For players, the training sessions at clubs during this time are a lot shorter. It is less tactical and more focused on individual stuff so Amorim will not be able to get a lot of his philosophy and ideas across to players.
final_quotes.quote_summary: The international break is challenging, especially with Amorim's style, as club training is shorter and less tactical during this period.

final_quotes.speaker: Fara Williams
final_quotes.quote_raw: Manchester United is a massive club and what this does is give the new boss time to see what the place is about. He will have more time to do that coming in during an international break than he would have done if he came in with back-to-back games straight away.
final_quotes.quote_summary: The international break gives Amorim more time to acclimate to Manchester United.

final_quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim
final_quotes.quote_raw: You watch on TV and you know that it's big and it's impressive - but when you are here, you can feel it and I think you feel the history. I'm really, really proud to be a Manchester United coach, so it's amazing. It's a real honour to be here.
final_quotes.quote_summary: The club's size and history are truly felt when you're here. I'm incredibly proud and honored to be the Manchester United coach.

final_quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim
final_quotes.quote_raw: That's really funny because I feel very relaxed. Maybe because it’s not gameday. When we have a game I'm a different guy, but I really don't feel the weight. I'm really excited and I'm quite relaxed. I think I am where I am supposed to be. That's the feeling.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Surprisingly, I'm very relaxed, perhaps because it's not a matchday. I don't feel the pressure. I'm excited and feel I'm in the right place.

final_quotes.speaker: Altrincham's commentator
final_quotes.quote_raw: He comes Ennis again. He's been excellent again, hasn't he? He's really lively
final_quotes.quote_summary: Ennis has been excellent and lively.

final_quotes.speaker: Reviewer
final_quotes.quote_raw: Lovely pillows with that crunchy hotel feel. Extremely comfy, full bounce-back.
final_quotes.quote_summary: These pillows feel like comfortable hotel pillows.

final_quotes.speaker: Witness
final_quotes.quote_raw: All the smoke was coming out of the house.
final_quotes.quote_summary: The house was filled with smoke.

final_quotes.speaker: Snooker lounge representative
final_quotes.quote_raw: We want to create a safe space for people.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Our aim is to provide a safe environment.
final_quotes.invalid_reason: Speaker is not a public figure.

final_quotes.speaker: Alan Embling
final_quotes.quote_raw: Let's be honest, if it wasn't for John Henry Davies, the brewer, and James Gibson there would be no Manchester United now. He rebuilt the club not once but twice. People forget that Old Trafford was a bomb site after the war and it all started when he attended a dinner.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Without John Henry Davies and James Gibson, Manchester United wouldn't exist. Gibson rebuilt the club twice, including Old Trafford after the war.

final_quotes.speaker: Alan Embling
final_quotes.quote_raw: He was approached by a journalist who told him United were in a terrible state and nobody wanted to help them, so he said he would look at it and looked at the books.
final_quotes.quote_summary: A journalist informed Gibson of United's dire situation, prompting him to examine the club's finances.

final_quotes.speaker: Alan Embling
final_quotes.quote_raw: The finances were a total disaster, all the good players had been sold off and the supporters were leaving in droves, but he gave a cheque of £2,000 and it was a gift, no strings attached.
final_quotes.quote_summary: United's finances were disastrous, players were sold, and fans were leaving, but Gibson donated £2,000 without conditions.

final_quotes.speaker: Alan Embling
final_quotes.quote_raw: They hadn't being paying the players' salaries for a long time and there was a huge backlog. It was just before Christmas and he covered the salaries up to January with the promise that he would see if he could help further, and he thought there was enough room in Manchester for two football clubs.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Gibson covered the players' overdue salaries before Christmas, promising to assess further assistance, believing Manchester could support two clubs.

final_quotes.speaker: Alan Embling
final_quotes.quote_raw: He decided to help and he did. He became the chairman and part of the £2,000 was so the players could buy the biggest Turkeys they could get their hands on for Christmas.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Gibson became chairman and used some of the £2,000 to ensure the players had a good Christmas.

final_quotes.speaker: Alan Embling
final_quotes.quote_raw: However, they were losing games and supporters were disappearing, so he held a meeting with fans and started to turn the club around. He rebuilt the club and it was incredible.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Despite initial struggles, Gibson engaged with fans and successfully turned the club around.

final_quotes.speaker: Alan Embling
final_quotes.quote_raw: At that time, Old Trafford was quite a way out, it was isolated, so he negotiated with the railway authorities to stop passenger trains on matchdays so fans could use the trains to get to the games on matchdays.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Gibson improved transport links to Old Trafford by arranging for trains to stop there on matchdays.

final_quotes.speaker: Alan Embling
final_quotes.quote_raw: James Gibson always considered supporters, who were the most important thing to him. However, he was paying transfer fees from his own pocket the whole time, so what he did with Walter Crickmer was create MUJAC, which stood for Manchester United Junior Athletic Club.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Gibson prioritized supporters and, to address funding transfer fees, created MUJAC, the precursor to the youth academy.

final_quotes.speaker: Alan Embling
final_quotes.quote_raw: That was the foundation and the start of the youth policy, which was the first in the country, and the only thing he said was he wanted as much local youth as possible. He wanted to support them, he was very community minded and he wanted to do it for the local people.
final_quotes.quote_summary: MUJAC was the foundation of the first youth policy in the country, prioritizing local talent.

final_quotes.speaker: Alan Embling
final_quotes.quote_raw: Gibson was a man of vision, he was ahead of his time. He'd been very lucky, he'd made a lot of money and was a hard working businessman, and the benefit of that was he was able to save Manchester United from extinction because the bank had closed on them.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Gibson's vision and business acumen allowed him to save Manchester United from bankruptcy.

final_quotes.speaker: Alan Embling
final_quotes.quote_raw: People had very little in their lives at that time and mostly going to the football after they worked hard all week was there only form of enjoyment. He gave that pleasure back to the people.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Gibson restored the joy of football to the people, which was their primary source of entertainment at the time.

final_quotes.speaker: Scott Duncan
final_quotes.quote_raw: By running a team in the Manchester League, we shall be able to give all likely juniors a chance of showing their paces, and United hope to discover from their number more than average finds.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Our Manchester League team will allow promising juniors to showcase their skills, hoping to uncover exceptional talent.

final_quotes.speaker: Scott Duncan
final_quotes.quote_raw: We will develop their muscles and build up their frame so that in time they could step in [to the first-team] and do themselves justice.
final_quotes.quote_summary: We'll physically develop youngsters so they're ready for the first-team.

final_quotes.speaker: Scott Duncan
final_quotes.quote_raw: To hurry along a youngster is a big mistake, but the junior must be assured that his time will come.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Rushing young players is a mistake, but they must be assured of their future opportunity.

final_quotes.speaker: Alan Embling
final_quotes.quote_raw: The war smashed the whole lot down. He managed to rebuild it on a shoe string budget because houses, factories and everything took precedence over sporting facilities.
final_quotes.quote_summary: The war destroyed Old Trafford, and Gibson rebuilt it with a limited budget due to other priorities.

final_quotes.speaker: Alan Embling
final_quotes.quote_raw: And whilst he was busy negotiating with the government for United to get their grants and licence to rebuild, he helped nine other football clubs to get their grants to rebuild their stadiums.
final_quotes.quote_summary: While securing funding for Old Trafford's reconstruction, Gibson helped nine other clubs get grants for their stadiums.

final_quotes.speaker: Alan Embling
final_quotes.quote_raw: United were lucky a lot of the youngsters came back and the only condition he put on them was if they were good enough to play professionally, they would be considered. There was no 'you've got to play them', it was 'consider' and one of the first names was Charlie Mitten.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Many young players returned after the war and Gibson's only condition was that they be considered for professional play if good enough.

final_quotes.speaker: Alan Embling
final_quotes.quote_raw: I'm the only living person now who knew James Gibson. I can remember him before he had a stroke, but mainly, of course, my memories are from after the stroke.
final_quotes.quote_summary: I'm the last living person who knew James Gibson, primarily remembering him after his stroke.

final_quotes.speaker: Alan Embling
final_quotes.quote_raw: He didn't go to the '48 FA Cup final because of that stroke and was presented with the cup in his home. That was incredible and he told Matt Busby that he'd made his dreams come true.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Due to a stroke, Gibson couldn't attend the '48 FA Cup final but received the cup at home, expressing to Busby that his dreams were fulfilled.

final_quotes.speaker: Alan Embling
final_quotes.quote_raw: Unfortunately as I got older, I found out that a lot of people didn't know who James Gibson was and what he did has all been eroded away, which is wrong.
final_quotes.quote_summary: It's unfortunate that Gibson's legacy has been forgotten.

final_quotes.speaker: Alan Embling
final_quotes.quote_raw: What that man did was incredible. He didn't even cash from merchandising, sponsorship or the television and we've even found clothing coupons that he provided for the kits.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Gibson's contributions were remarkable, even providing clothing coupons for kits without personal financial gain.

final_quotes.speaker: Alan Embling
final_quotes.quote_raw: The Gibsons were a dying breed. They were the people who looked after supporters, but when the big sponsorships came in, the big money men came in and fans were forgotten about. So much has been lost. United was like a family and you don't have that in the same these days.
final_quotes.quote_summary: People like Gibson, who prioritized supporters, are rare now. The focus has shifted from fans to financial gains.

final_quotes.speaker: Alan Embling
final_quotes.quote_raw: United should play more acknowledgment to two of the greatest men in the club history, James Gibson and John Davies, the brewer, because those two men were incredible.
final_quotes.quote_summary: United should give more recognition to Gibson and Davies for their immense contributions.

final_quotes.speaker: Alan Embling
final_quotes.quote_raw: Without them, there wouldn't be all those people enjoying football at Old Trafford now and I hope if they have to build a new stadium, something is done to keep the memorial.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Without Gibson and Davies, Old Trafford wouldn't be what it is today, and their memorial should be preserved in any new stadium.

final_quotes.speaker: Erik ten Hag
final_quotes.quote_raw: Dear fans, Let me start by thanking you. Thank you for always being there for the club. Whether it was at a game far away or a tough match at Old Trafford, your support has been unshakeable. The atmosphere at Old Trafford has always been electrifying, thanks to you. I felt it many times. Also in away games, it gave the team and me an incredible feeling to hear the United chants taking over the opponents stadiums, whether the game was in England. Europe or during the summer tours. I always enjoyed meeting Manchester United fans throughout the world. Walking the streets and being able to chat with fans in England, Europe, Asia, Australia, the USA - you inspired me and radiated a strong sense of unity. That's what makes United supporters so special. I want to thank you for giving me this feeling and for your support. I also want to thank the staff in every department of the club for their unwavering support in good times and bad. We won two trophies - achievements that I will cherish for the rest of my life. Of course, my dream was to bring more trophies to the cabinet. Unfortunately, that dream has come to an end. I wish all Manchester United fans nothing but success, trophies and glory. Your support and the warmth I received from everyone at the club helped me feel at home. Thank you for this chapter in my life.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Thank you to the fans and staff for your unwavering support. Winning two trophies was a highlight, although I dreamt of more.  I wish the club and fans future success.

final_quotes.quote_summary: These pillows feel like premium hotel pillows, very comfortable and springy.

final_quotes.speaker: Bruno Fernandes
final_quotes.quote_raw: I have played, however, especially last season with coach Ten Hag, deeper. In fact, against Everton, I played No.6 and I still think it was one of the most complete games I've played, at all levels. In terms of passing, game organisation, defence, tactics. I have a little thought in my head that I'm going to end my career further back, because everyone who started there and went to No.10 ended up retreating on the field at the end. It's a position I like, playing deeper, facing the game more. With the ball, it makes my game a lot easier because I have a broader view of the game and it is ideal for what we've talked about with the last pass, which can sometimes come from deeper on the pitch. The game with Everton was the one in which I created the most scoring opportunities, even though I was playing deeper and not playing as a No.10.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Last season I played deeper, even as a No.6 against Everton, which I felt was one of my most well-rounded performances. I'm considering finishing my career in a deeper role for better game management and passing opportunities, as demonstrated in the Everton match where I created numerous chances despite not playing as a No.10.

final_quotes.speaker: Matteo Darmian
final_quotes.quote_raw: When I signed for Manchester United, I discovered that in England, during away games, family members don’t have a reserved section; they sit among the fans. The first match was the derby against Liverpool. I told my girlfriend: ‘Look, it’s a very intense match. Do you still want to come?’ And she said: ‘Yes, of course, I really care.’ So, she got in the car with the steering wheel on the right and went into the away section. For a footballer, the English football culture brings less pressure. During the week, there’s less talk about football; the weekend and the experience of going to the stadium are more important.
final_quotes.quote_summary: In England, families sit with fans at away games. My girlfriend even drove herself to the Liverpool derby! Football culture here is less pressured, focused on the stadium experience.

final_quotes.speaker: Matteo Darmian
final_quotes.quote_raw: As soon as I arrived in Manchester, I discovered a completely new world. In Italy, very few players had social media profiles. In England, on my first day, they immediately told me to open an Instagram account and that I would need to participate in commercial initiatives. What now seems normal wasn’t back then. There were so many commercial activities; it was a completely different world from what I was used to. In the following years, Pogba and Ibrahimovic also arrived, and they were media superstars.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Arriving at Manchester United was a whole new world.  I was immediately told to open an Instagram and participate in commercial activities. It was very different from Italy where few players had social media.  Later, big media stars like Pogba and Ibrahimovic joined.

final_quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim
final_quotes.quote_raw: I think you will see an idea. You could like it or not, I don't know, but you will see an idea. You will see a positioning. You will see something.
final_quotes.quote_summary: You'll definitely see a clear tactical approach from my team, whether you appreciate it or not.

final_quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim
final_quotes.quote_raw: Something that we want to reach that kind of level. You will feel that. But we have to know that it's like two training [sessions] before the first match. This is the best league in the world. But if I have to say something to you, you will see an idea. This I can guarantee.
final_quotes.quote_summary: We aim for a certain level of play, and you'll sense it, despite only having two training sessions. This league is highly competitive, but I assure you, there will be a noticeable strategy.

final_quotes.speaker: Alfredo Fumacas
final_quotes.quote_raw: With a mixture of cautious optimism and suspicion
final_quotes.quote_summary: We're cautiously optimistic but also suspicious.

final_quotes.speaker: Alfredo Fumacas
final_quotes.quote_raw: Of course there's concern from Benfica. Benfica initially brought in Carreras on a loan, but activated the buy clause of €6m in the beginning of the season, knowing that there was a buy back clause of €20m, at the time there were some questions from the fans in terms of his worth. I don't believe Benfica expected Carreras to rise up this quickly and to be on the radar of many European clubs, usually Benfica can keep suitors at bay with high release causes, but €20m will be a bargain for a 21-year-old with lots of potential.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Benfica are concerned about losing Carreras, especially given his rapid rise and the relatively low buy-back clause. They didn't anticipate his value increasing so fast.

final_quotes.speaker: Alfredo Fumacas
final_quotes.quote_raw: On paper he is a good fit, along with doing very well covering the left flank and combining well with his teammates. He has also played as a third centre-half at Benfica during some tactical variations by Lage. He likes to associate with the midfield in the build-up process, and does very well in short combinations, and getting into the final third - reminiscent of Alejandro Grimaldo, but with more of a defensive ability to his game. I feel Carreras is doing well at Benfica because of the trust Lage has put in him, and because he has been able to win the hearts of the fans with his performances. Playing at Old Trafford, where he didn't have the best of times, endured rejection, albeit normal for the process of a young player, may be something that will weigh on his psyche, but we are also talking about a 21 year old Carreras who has evolved mentally with the experiences he's had.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Carreras is a good fit for United on paper. He's strong defensively and offensively, comfortable playing various roles. While his previous experience at Old Trafford might affect him, he has grown a lot and Lage's trust has been beneficial.

final_quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim
final_quotes.quote_raw: probably already has a number of strikers
final_quotes.quote_summary: United already has enough strikers.

final_quotes.speaker: Viktor Gyokeres
final_quotes.quote_raw: we'll see
final_quotes.quote_summary: We'll see what the future holds.
final_quotes.invalid_reason: Speaker is random and not a public figure.

final_quotes.speaker: Jose Fonte
final_quotes.quote_raw: Portuguese clubs have got no option but to sell for the right price. We need to sell. Portuguese clubs have to sell one or two players every season. We don't have the same TV rights as the Premier League so we don't have the capacity to hold on to players. It would be lovely to see Portugal with a little bit more capacity to hold on to their talent, of course.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Portuguese clubs must sell players to survive financially due to lower TV revenue compared to the Premier League.  We'd prefer to keep our talent, but it's necessary.

final_quotes.speaker: Jose Fonte
final_quotes.quote_raw: That's what people in the various federations are trying to do. Sporting will listen and they will probably have to sell Viktor Gyokeres because Portuguese clubs have to raise big money every year.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Federations are working to change the financial situation, but Sporting likely will have to sell Gyokeres due to financial pressures.

final_quotes.speaker: Hasan Cetinkaya
final_quotes.quote_raw: Everyone paid more to Viktor, everyone paid a higher commission to the agent. What happened? I brought him to Sporting because of Ruben Amorim, because I know his work and his work with the players. I chose Ruben because he is a coach of another level. And, yes, it will be more difficult for Viktor to stay if Ruben Amorim leaves Sporting because Viktor came precisely because of Ruben. The day we met, we told Ruben: 'here's my boy, he came to Sporting because of you.'
final_quotes.quote_summary: I brought Gyokeres to Sporting specifically for Amorim; better offers and commissions were available elsewhere. Gyokeres is likely to follow Amorim if he leaves.

final_quotes.speaker: Viktor Gyokeres
final_quotes.quote_raw: It's not something I'm thinking about. I want to finish the season at Sporting, I'm enjoying playing there. I'm in no rush to make a change in the future. We'll see when the time comes for that.
final_quotes.quote_summary: I'm focused on finishing the season at Sporting and not currently thinking about transferring.

final_quotes.speaker: Viktor Gyokeres
final_quotes.quote_raw: The most important thing is to have an important role in the team and be able to play. There are other factors that may play a role, but I will look at that when the time comes.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Playing a key role will be my priority when considering future transfers.

final_quotes.speaker: Adan
final_quotes.quote_raw: Real Madrid or Atletico? I think maybe he has more of an Atletico de Madrid profile. Physically, he's a beast. Potentially, he's an animal, and in front of goal, he's a killer. It seemed like there was no way he could repeat what he did last year, and there's this amount of goals. Plus, this year, with the protagonism of doing so in the Champions League.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Gyokeres's playing style, being a strong and prolific scorer, fits Atletico Madrid more than Real Madrid.  He's continued his excellent performance from last year into the Champions League this year.

final_quotes.speaker: Adan
final_quotes.quote_raw: Well, I think he has that profile. It's true that he's a little shorter, but in terms of strength, determination in the box, he has that killer instinct of scoring a lot of goals. He shows spectacular competitiveness every day in training.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Gyokeres has a similar profile to Haaland in terms of strength and goal-scoring instinct, showing his competitiveness daily.

final_quotes.speaker: Yvon Mvogo
final_quotes.quote_raw: Correct [top clubs wanted me as a No.2], Manchester United, for example. But that wasn't an option for me. I'm not happy if I can't be on the pitch. I want to enjoy my time on the pitch right now, together with fans and teammates. I want to play for titles and ideally win them too.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Top clubs like Manchester United wanted me as a backup, but I declined. I want to play regularly, enjoy the game with fans and teammates, and compete for titles.

final_quotes.speaker: Yvon Mvogo
final_quotes.quote_raw: Getting promoted again with Lorient next spring is definitely my goal. We will see what happens after that and I don't want to predict anything. I have now noticed how quickly things can happen in the football business.
final_quotes.quote_summary: My main goal is to help Lorient get promoted. I'll assess my options after that, as things change rapidly in football.

final_quotes.speaker: Richard Keys
final_quotes.quote_raw: Every briefing coming out of OT underlines what a cataclysmic mistake it was keeping ten Toast (sic) last summer. They let him spend another £200m+ on rubbish & now there’s nothing for Amorim. Somebody in the brains trust should be fired. There’s nothing for Amorim to work with.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Keeping Ten Hag last summer was a huge mistake. He wasted over £200m, leaving Amorim with nothing. Someone should be held accountable.

final_quotes.speaker: Roy Keane
final_quotes.quote_raw: I do think the players, obviously, get away with murder.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Players get away with too much.

final_quotes.speaker: Roy Keane
final_quotes.quote_raw: Just the way they hide behind the manager, Mourinho. Whatever you say about the players, they have thrown him under the bus. People have said Mourinho has been falling out with players, well you would fall out with players. That's the name of the game, players turn up overweight or players are not training properly and not producing. And then for some of them to down tools, you know, shame on some of them players. I'm not Mourinho's biggest fan, don't get me wrong, but I just can't tolerate footballers who hide behind agents, their pals in the media. A bit of a joke, really.
final_quotes.quote_summary: The players, not Mourinho, are to blame. Some don't train properly, are overweight, and hide behind their agents and the media. It's shameful.

final_quotes.speaker: Rene van der Gijp
final_quotes.quote_raw: Suppose we are in the stands together as a scout for Manchester City or Liverpool... and we are looking at Antony, what do you think we would say when we come back on Monday? We will not take that. You don’t see a Serge Gnabry, Leroy Sane or Mohamed Salah doing this. Then you can say, 'He is young'. But it can also get crazier.
final_quotes.quote_summary: If we were scouting Antony for City or Liverpool, his behavior would be a major turn-off.  Top players like Gnabry, Sane, or Salah don't act like that, regardless of age.

final_quotes.speaker: Wim Kieft
final_quotes.quote_raw: He is not that young anymore, because he has been doing this for two years. Such a boy cannot be calmed by a coach, in the end. Ten Hag will of course never say that Antony behaves like an idiot, but he thinks so. In general, this behaviour is addressed in the locker room. Then someone says, 'Hey, what are you doing?'
final_quotes.quote_summary: He's been acting this way for a while now, and a coach can't fix that.  Even though Ten Hag wouldn't say it publicly, he likely agrees Antony acts foolishly.  This sort of thing gets addressed internally by the team.

final_quotes.speaker: Casemiro
final_quotes.quote_raw: Top training
final_quotes.quote_summary: Excellent training session.

You can see the second half he was up there and then he can express his leadership, he can express his defensive qualities and rest on the ball, we especially needed that in this back four.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Harry Maguire recovered from a first-half issue and demonstrated his leadership and defensive skills, which were crucial for us.

final_quotes.quote_raw: It is about a culture and every player has to match certain standards. What will happen there, he knows what he has to do if he wants to return and it is up to him. We will see what will happen.
final_quotes.quote_summary: It's about the culture and meeting standards. Sancho knows what's required for his return.  It's up to him.

final_quotes.speaker: Raphael Varane
final_quotes.quote_raw: As someone who has played international and Champions League football, I feel extremely lucky to have done so. I also know what is required to get here. A critical element of reaching the top level is making the right decisions for yourself. Many of these decisions stem from ego, something that for me is one of the most important things to keep control of, and can give you a better mentality when used correctly. In football and in life, I have found that, as long as you have a strong mindset and continue to act on it, you can reach new heights. The accolades and recognition you get are a consequence of the decisions you make. If you focus on the process and enjoy the small improvements rather than only focusing on the result, you can always achieve great things.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Reaching the top level requires making the right decisions and controlling your ego. A strong mindset and focus on the process are key to success.

final_quotes.quote_summary: We can't tell the twins apart on the field.
