final_quotes.quote_raw: keep it as low-key as possible
final_quotes.quote_summary: We're trying to avoid too much attention on the twins.

final_quotes.speaker: Dan Gore
final_quotes.quote_raw: It tops the list of birthdays. I don’t think words can describe that feeling, seeing the fans, it is everything you’ve dreamed of, coming true. It means everything.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Making my debut for the club I've supported since childhood on my 19th birthday was an indescribable, dream-come-true experience.

final_quotes.speaker: Lewis Craig
final_quotes.quote_raw:
He first came through the door when he was seven or eight. Burnley were very good at recruiting the Scouse and Manc kids and Dan was a raw, inner-city Manchester lad. Those types seemed to have that little bit more extra bite than your local kids. He was a forward when he came to us and he’d either play wide left or right or as the number nine and he was the top scorer through his age groups. He was quick and very strong for his size. He always had aggression and he was one of the kids who played on the edge, in terms of maybe making the odd bad challenge, but it was interesting because he was always respectful. He had great finishing ability in his younger years, one-on-one, going past people and he always had that bit where he was a winner. If he was getting beat, there was nobody on the pitch who hated it more and you could see that fire in him. Dan had that brilliant, real f
***** horrible side to him, but he'd always be respectful with coaches and it wasn't a surprise when I saw him three months ago and he ran over and gave me a hug when I hadn’t seen him for years.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Dan Gore was a raw, aggressive, and naturally talented forward at Burnley from a young age, always striving to win, while also demonstrating respect to coaches.

final_quotes.speaker: Lewis Craig
final_quotes.quote_raw: My last day working for Burnley, I had to deliver his review to his dad. Although he was a great striker, I didn’t think he scored poachers goals, like your Harry Kane or Ole Gunnar Solskjaer. He scored amazing goals and he was off the charts, but I thought he could be a better instinctive finisher. I remember his dad saying thank you because all he'd had for a couple of years was people telling him how good he was and nobody had said things to work on. He was prolific and he’d beat a few men and fire one into the top corner, but if someone wrapped a ball across the 18-yard box at speed, he probably didn’t have that instinctive finish in him every time. But he worked on it religiously. He always worked on stuff and he was in training early, even as a kid. I never pictured him as a midfielder because although his awareness was decent, it's different playing in that role. He’s developed his awareness now and when I see him driving the ball in midfield, it’s similar to how he played back then.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Despite Dan Gore's impressive goal-scoring record as a young striker at Burnley, I believed his finishing could be more instinctive, although he diligently worked on it. I never envisioned him as a midfielder but his awareness has developed significantly.

final_quotes.speaker: Mike Hargreaves
final_quotes.quote_raw: I worked with Danny at Burnley from Under-9s to Under-12s and I took that age group all the way through, so I worked with him for quite a while, and outside of Burnley with my own coaching. Some of the things I’ve seen him do for United, he’s been doing since back then. He’s dropped deeper now, but when he played up front for Burnley he'd score over 100 goals each season and I’m not even exaggerating. There was a game at Blackburn once when we built possession well, Dan picked the ball up inside his own half and he just started running past people and he ended up finishing it off, which was unbelievable. There was another time when he faced someone up, stopped the ball dead and did the Yannick Bolaise showboating thing when he bent down and flicked the grass, so he had a little bit of cheekiness about him. He was a matchwinner and they were a really good group. I always thought It was just a matter of time before United would come in for him and I always expected that. I can’t think of many times he didn't have a good day.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Even at a young age with Burnley, Dan exhibited the same skills he demonstrates now at United. He consistently scored over 100 goals a season, possessed exciting dribbling skills, and a cheeky confidence on the pitch. He was a natural match-winner.

final_quotes.speaker: Mike Hargreaves
final_quotes.quote_raw: His real stand-out qualities were he was hard-working, aggressive, he put himself about and he was a really exciting dribbler. He was fantastic with the ball and capable of sprinting repeatedly. His speed endurance was phenomenal, even at those ages. His attitude was great and he was demanding of his teammates and the standards of the session. Towards the end of Under-11s, we had a tournament on Blackpool’s pitch and it was a full-day affair. We played United in the final of that and Danny scored. They were just completely top draw that day as a group. I remember building up to that tournament for a few weeks and reiterating what we were building up to and you’d see a change in him, almost like a switch being flicked and a refocus. You could see he wanted to win.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Dan was always a hard worker, aggressive, and an exciting dribbler with remarkable speed and endurance. His attitude was excellent, demanding of both himself and his teammates. His drive to win was especially evident in the lead-up to and during a tournament final against United.

final_quotes.speaker: Lewis Craig
final_quotes.quote_raw: He’s captain material I'd say. Almost like your old-school Roy Keane type with hard challenges, but he’s got unbelievable quality on the ball because he was a forward in the past as well. In that Under-21 group at United, there have been the likes of Shola Shoretire and Isak Hasen-Aaroen but it seems like there's been something missing in them, which doesn’t seem to be the case with Dan. If you leave him in an environment long enough he thrives and I think it's fair to say that Dan wasn’t a Burnley type of player, in the sense that he was probably beyond Burnley in terms of his ability. He would have played for Burnley’s first-team if he was still there and Sean Dyche would have been all over him, but there was always an acceptance of Dan was Salford, Man United and there were murmurings going on in the background. Kids get poached in academies all the time, but I think Burnley got looked after with the deal when he did go over. And I think he was given certain guarantees because United knew the talent they were getting.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Dan has the qualities of a captain, reminiscent of Roy Keane's style. His abilities exceeded Burnley's environment and while he would likely have thrived there under Sean Dyche, his natural path seemed destined for Manchester United.

final_quotes.speaker: Lewis Craig
final_quotes.quote_raw: You can tell what Manchester United means to him when he plays. I went to the Youth Cup final and I just thought he was outstanding, doing the horrible side of the game really well. I thought out of possession, Dan was excellent, picking up second balls and showing all the stuff he's added to his game as a midfielder and you can see he's got a real understanding of the game now.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Dan's passion for Manchester United is evident in his play. His performance in the Youth Cup final was exceptional, particularly his work ethic and strategic understanding of the game as a midfielder.

final_quotes.speaker: Mike Hargreaves
final_quotes.quote_raw: I saw him right at the end when they were doing the lap of honour because I was sitting near the front, so I went down and shouted. He said 'aaaah Mike!' and I congratulated him, so it was nice to have that moment and I did have to laugh because near the end of the Youth Cup final, he was tapping his head and telling people to focus. That’s stuck with me because it’s something I do myself. We had great times at Burnley and he was the star of the group. I’ve got a great relationship with him and his dad, who was always very grateful for us looking after him.
final_quotes.quote_summary: It was great to see Dan after his Youth Cup final win, even reminding his teammates to stay focused near the end. He was always the standout player and his dad appreciated how he was cared for at Burnley.

final_quotes.speaker: Lewis Craig
final_quotes.quote_raw: You’re around top players every day at United and you either adapt or die. Even if he ends up making 100 appearances for United in the Premier League or with another club, he'll get the most out of himself. Ten Hag has been known for developing youngsters at Ajax and he doesn’t put people in who aren’t good enough. I'm really proud of him and it's lovely when you bump into him, or get a text.
final_quotes.quote_summary: At United, you must adapt to the high level of play. Dan will succeed regardless of where he ends up, and Ten Hag's trust in him speaks volumes about his talent. I'm incredibly proud of his achievements.

final_quotes.speaker: Mike Hargreaves
final_quotes.quote_raw: It’s been brilliant to see him progress and I’m a United fan myself, so I'm extremely pleased because it's more than he deserves. I genuinely think he embodies what a United player should be, bringing excitement, being hard-working and holding himself in the right way.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Dan's progression is fantastic, and as a United fan, I'm thrilled for him. His hard work, exciting play, and conduct embody what a United player represents.

final_quotes.speaker: Christian Eriksen
final_quotes.quote_raw: I haven't focused on it yet, and I haven't heard anything from the club. Right now it's just about football, and then we have to see where we stand in January and for that matter in the summer.
final_quotes.quote_summary: I haven't thought about my future yet, and the club hasn't said anything.  I'm focused on playing right now, and we'll see what happens in January or the summer.

final_quotes.speaker: Ruud van Nistelrooy
final_quotes.quote_raw: To everyone at Manchester United Football Club, in particular the backroom staff, the players and the fans. I want to thank you from the bottom of my heart for your incredible efforts and support. It has been a privilege and honour to represent the club as a player, coach and manager, and I will always cherish the memories we have shared together. Man United will always have a special place in my heart, and I hope there are many more glory days at Old Trafford very soon - not only because I want the club to do well, but because you all deserve it! All the best and take care.
final_quotes.quote_summary: I want to thank everyone at Manchester United for their support. It's been an honor to represent the club, and I cherish the memories. I wish the club many more glory days.

final_quotes.speaker: Wes Brown
final_quotes.quote_raw: With everyone fit, I'd like to see a back three of Leny Yoro, Matthijs de Ligt and Lisandro Martinez in front of Andre Onana. I'd like to see Bruno Fernandes and Kobbie Mainoo in the middle with Diogo Dalot and Noussair Mazraoui as wing-backs. Then Alejandro Garnacho and Marcus Rashford in behind Rasmus Hojlund. That team has plenty of creativity as well as pace at the back, but I’m sure everyone under Amorim will get a chance to impress.
final_quotes.quote_summary: My ideal starting XI under Amorim: Yoro, De Ligt, and Martinez in defense; Dalot and Mazraoui as wing-backs; Fernandes and Mainoo in midfield; Garnacho and Rashford behind Hojlund. This lineup offers creativity, pace, and I believe everyone will get a chance to shine.

final_quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim
final_quotes.quote_raw: I think you will see an idea. You could like it or not, I don't know, but you will see an idea. You will see a positioning. You will see something that we want to reach that kind of level. You will feel that. We have to know that it's like two trainings before the first match. This is the best league in the world. But if I have to say something to you, [it's that] you will see an idea. This I can guarantee.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Despite having limited training time before our first match in this demanding league, you will see a clear tactical idea and our intended playing style.

final_quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim
final_quotes.quote_raw: A lot of people now talk about the 3-4-3 and the 4-3-3 and all that stuff. But when I think as a player or as a team-mate of [Manchester United], it is not a system or formation – it's like the character of the players, the way they see the club. So we have to focus on that before everything [in terms] of how we play, how we press. The most important thing for me, at this moment, is to create the principles, the identity and the character that we had in the past.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Tactical formations are secondary to the players' character and their connection with the club. Rebuilding the team's principles, identity, and past character is my priority.

final_quotes.speaker: Andy Robertson
final_quotes.quote_raw: To do it so late on and it means something, now we get the play-off in March, it's very important and I think it was what the performance deserved. I don't think anyone can argue that. I thought we dominated, I thought we played well. We got done by an unbelievable goal, from their perspective, but I think our performance deserved the win and I'm just happy to step up at the last minute to make sure that the lads got what we deserved.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Scoring so late to secure the March play-off was important and deserved, especially after conceding such an impressive goal from the other team.

final_quotes.speaker: Andy Robertson
final_quotes.quote_raw: First cap to 80th cap. Same stadium, same feeling! Proud to join the legend Darren Fletcher as third-most capped. The win was the cherry on top of the cake, see you all in March.
final_quotes.quote_summary: From my first cap to my 80th, it feels the same. Proud to equal Darren Fletcher's cap record, and winning topped it off.

We need to be competitive to add to the group, it’s getting harder and harder to get into the starting eleven. There’s a World Cup finals in 18 months. The game against Croatia is important, we need to look at other players. We’re going to let go of Bernardo Silva, Pedro Neto, Cristiano Ronaldo and Bruno Fernandes, who is suspended – so we’re going to call up Fabio Silva and [Geovany] Quenda from the Under-21s.
final_quotes.quote_summary: We rotated the squad heavily in the first stage.  Securing the top spot was key, and we've achieved that. Competition for places is intensifying with the World Cup approaching. The Croatia game allows us to assess other players. With some players unavailable, we'll bring in some U21s.

final_quotes.speaker: Michael Carrick
final_quotes.quote_raw: It's obviously a big challenge, an incredible football club, obviously huge, and gig expectation. It's where you want to be in terms of testing yourselve against the best, he's there and I hope he does well. I'm obviously a supporter, my family are, and we love the club aswell so I really hope it works out. There's good players there, good people at the club, hopefully he goes there and settles really quickly.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Managing Manchester United is a huge challenge with high expectations, but I hope Amorim thrives. I'm a supporter and hope it works out for him.

final_quotes.speaker: Mark Ashton
final_quotes.quote_raw: Our opening game of the season was Liverpool at home. We thought that was big. We then went away to Man City in the second game. We thought that was big. This is going to be huge. The eyes of the world are upon us on and off the pitch. It's a chance for us to be the best version of ourselves and show Ipswich as a club, a town and a community to the world. That's the platform that the Premier League gives you. I'm also buzzing for Kieran [McKenna] to be given the opportunity to pit his wits against his former club.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Playing against Liverpool and Man City were big, but facing Man United will be huge, with global attention. It's a chance for Ipswich to showcase ourselves to the world. I'm thrilled for Kieran McKenna to face his old club.

final_quotes.speaker: Gary Pallister
final_quotes.quote_raw: I think Manchester United will keep looking at that centre-forward position as an area they can strengthen. We’ll see whether that’s a position Ruben Amorim will be able to address in January and whether he’ll be able to bring Viktor Gyökeres from Sporting in with him in the near future. He’s certainly enjoyed scoring a lot of goals in Portugal and for Coventry over the past couple of years and Manchester United have been waiting to have a natural goalscorer up front for a few years now, so he fits the bill in that respect.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Man United needs a stronger centre-forward, and Gyökeres' goal-scoring record makes him a suitable candidate.

final_quotes.speaker: Christian Eriksen
final_quotes.quote_raw: It’s not really up to me when my contract runs out, it’s up to the club. When the summer comes if the offer is there I will definitely take it seriously.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Contract renewal is the club's decision, but I'll consider any offer seriously in the summer.

final_quotes.speaker: Viktor Gyokeres
final_quotes.quote_raw: It's very sad that he's leaving, but of course we understand his decision. He has of course meant a lot, considering that he gave me that chance and that he made me develop so much.
final_quotes.quote_summary: While I'm sad about his departure, I understand his reasons and am grateful for the opportunity and growth he provided me.

final_quotes.speaker: Viktor Gyokeres
final_quotes.quote_raw: He [Amorim] probably has some strikers there already, so we'll see. He hasn't [contacted me], it's fun but nothing I attach any importance to because it's talk and nothing concrete.
final_quotes.quote_summary: I'm aware of the rumors about Amorim wanting me at United, but they are unsubstantiated at this point.

final_quotes.speaker: Seydou Doumbia
final_quotes.quote_raw: He's had times where he's struggled, but I think this season he's been absolutely brilliant, overall. He absolutely deserves a new contract. Manchester United can't afford to rest on their laurels. He's a winger worth more than €40million (£33.4m). I love the way he receives the ball, is calm, his awareness of his surroundings and, of course, the big goals and chances he creates. He can be Ruben Amorim's Bukayo Saka.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Amad has been brilliant this season, deserves a new contract, and is a valuable player. His composure, awareness, and goal contributions are impressive. He has the potential to be Amorim's Saka.

final_quotes.speaker: Emmanuel Eboue
final_quotes.quote_raw: I think it's a no-brainer that Man United will give him a new contract. Every time he was given a chance, he always showed his goal. I think it will be even better with Amorim.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Giving Amad a new contract is obvious. He always delivers and will improve further under Amorim.

final_quotes.speaker: Ronald Koeman
final_quotes.quote_raw: For both Frenkie and Virgil it is better for them to leave the training camp at this moment. That decision was taken on medical grounds, with of course the interest of the players coming first.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Frenkie and Virgil's departure from training camp is in their best medical interest.

final_quotes.speaker: Grant McCann
final_quotes.quote_raw: We've had a couple of boys in this week from Man United. They've been training with us and that's been really good, just to have a look at them. We also sent two to Man United.
final_quotes.quote_summary: We've had a couple of Man United boys training with us this week, which has been beneficial. We also sent two of our players to them.

final_quotes.speaker: Grant McCann
final_quotes.quote_raw: It's about forming a relationship with them which is great and there's other clubs that want to do that as well and that speaks volumes about how we're playing and performing.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Building a relationship with Man United is great, and other clubs wanting the same shows how well we're doing.

final_quotes.speaker: Grant McCann
final_quotes.quote_raw: It's really good to have a chance to look at things like this. They're two of Man United's better U21 players and they both played in the game [behind-closed-doors] and were both excellent.
final_quotes.quote_summary: It's good to have this opportunity. The two Man United U21 players were excellent in the behind-closed-doors game.

final_quotes.speaker: Grant McCann
final_quotes.quote_raw: One's a wide player [Sharpe] and the other is a midfielder [McAllister].Travis [Binnion] has been brilliant with us and the fact we've managed to get Kasper and Sam in there is great, to show them what a Premier League club looks like but also to see they work and train and deliver sessions.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Sharpe is a wide player, McAllister a midfielder. Binnion has been great and it's good for our players to experience a Premier League club.

final_quotes.speaker: Grant McCann
final_quotes.quote_raw: It's been a worthwhile week and having that link with one of the biggest clubs in the world is huge. If you're a young player at Man United then you've got everything there. They have the best training ground, the best pitches, best food. Everything is just laid on for you.
final_quotes.quote_summary: This week's link with Man United has been invaluable. Young players there have everything provided for them.

final_quotes.speaker: Grant McCann
final_quotes.quote_raw: I remember when they came to us [EFL Trophy group game] wearing brand new Hugo Boss suits. We're in our tracksuits, so it's just a different world. But coming here gives them an insight into what it means to win three points as opposed to U21 football where it doesn't really matter. It's a huge thing.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Man United's players arrived in Hugo Boss suits, highlighting the different worlds. But training here shows them the importance of winning, unlike in U21 football.

final_quotes.speaker: Jim Thwaites
final_quotes.quote_raw: Delighted to get both U16 and U18 goal of the season. More to come next season..
final_quotes.quote_summary: Very happy to have won Goal of the Season for both U16 and U18, and I'm looking forward to achieving more next season.

final_quotes.speaker: Jim Thwaites
final_quotes.quote_raw: Good first session with the first team.
final_quotes.quote_summary: I had a good first training session with the main team.

final_quotes.speaker: Lionel Scaloni
final_quotes.quote_raw: We didn’t expect the case of Lisandro. We saw that he had suffered a blow to his back, but apparently, he had no problem, just pain. When he arrived here, the pain increased a bit, he underwent tests and is not fit to be here.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Lisandro's back injury was unexpected. He initially had pain, but tests showed he's unfit to play.

final_quotes.speaker: Emil Holm
final_quotes.quote_raw: It’s very sad. He just come back from injury and then to get another injury, you suffer with that. It was tough to see. He was very down in the dressing room too. He’s an important man in the team, he’s captain anyway. No, it was a shame. I gave him a hug and told him to get well.
final_quotes.quote_summary: It's sad that Lindelof got injured again right after returning. He's important to the team and was very upset. I offered my support.

final_quotes.speaker: Ruud van Nistelrooy
final_quotes.quote_raw: Harry [Maguire] is still working inside on his rehabilitation.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Harry Maguire is still working on his rehabilitation.

final_quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim
final_quotes.quote_raw: So, from day one, we will start with our identity. The most important thing for me at this moment is to create the principles, the identity and the character that we had in the past.
final_quotes.quote_summary: We'll begin by establishing our identity, focusing on recreating the principles, identity, and character of the past.

final_quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim
final_quotes.quote_raw: If you work as a team, then the talent individually is going to shine.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Individual talent flourishes when working effectively as a team.

final_quotes.speaker: Rebekah Vardy
final_quotes.quote_raw: That feeling when you are living rent free in people's heads
final_quotes.quote_summary: I'm living rent free in their heads!

final_quotes.speaker: Rebekah Vardy
final_quotes.quote_raw: [Responding to Coleen Rooney sinking twice] the gift that keeps on giving
final_quotes.quote_summary: Coleen sinking is hilarious!

final_quotes.speaker: Rebekah Vardy
final_quotes.quote_raw: Everyone thinks Jamie is mad at me for speaking out, but that couldn’t be further from the truth. He’s encouraging me, saying, ‘Give it to her, get the truth out there’. He loves it that she’s back getting headlines. The more stick he gets from the stands in football, the better he plays.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Jamie isn't mad, he actually encourages me to speak out against Coleen and loves the attention. He even plays better when fans taunt him.

final_quotes.speaker: Jamie Vardy
final_quotes.quote_raw: Give it to her, get the truth out there
final_quotes.quote_summary: Go Rebekah, expose the truth!

final_quotes.speaker: Marcel Reif
final_quotes.quote_raw: It’s no secret that he will probably move to Liverpool next summer. I would put a few euros on it. As the successor to his great idol Mo Salah. Things couldn’t get any better for him.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Omar Marmoush is likely to join Liverpool next summer, possibly as Salah's successor.

final_quotes.speaker: Markus Krosche
final_quotes.quote_raw: That [amount] won't be enough. It's often the case with many players who join us that we provide them with an environment where they can continue to develop—fully aware that we would let them go if they develop faster than the club itself. That's an agreement we make with the players.
final_quotes.quote_summary: €40m won't be enough for Marmoush. We help players develop and let them go if they outgrow the club.

final_quotes.speaker: Trent Alexander-Arnold
final_quotes.quote_raw: I would say Dele (Alli). My first few camps, when I was younger, and he was at the top of his game at that time.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Dele Alli was my toughest opponent in training, especially during my early days when he was at his peak.

final_quotes.speaker: Trent Alexander-Arnold
final_quotes.quote_raw: He was untouchable.
final_quotes.quote_summary: He was untouchable.

final_quotes.speaker: Dele Alli
final_quotes.quote_raw: I spoke about it in my interview and don't want to go over it too much again – but I know my level as a player and what I can get to. It's hard for me to even watch football. It's been tough for me, I'd say, this past eight months has been hard to watch.
final_quotes.quote_summary: I know my potential as a player, and though it's been tough, the past eight months have been challenging.

final_quotes.speaker: Dele Alli
final_quotes.quote_raw: You know you can set reminders on your phone, I have a reminder at 11 o'clock every day that says, 'World Cup 2026'. That's my aim for now. I think that people will be like, 'he hasn't played in a year,' but I don't care, I know my level.
final_quotes.quote_summary: I have daily reminders about the 2026 World Cup, which is my current goal, regardless of my playing time this year.

final_quotes.speaker: Oleksandr Zinchenko
final_quotes.quote_raw: [He] likes to play games with the opposition. I’ve seen him tell injured players to come on the team bus and walk into the dressing room with their wash bag to put the other manager off the scent.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Arteta tries to mislead the opposition by having injured players appear as if they are fit.

final_quotes.speaker: Mikel Arteta
final_quotes.quote_raw: He’s not fit’
final_quotes.quote_summary: If a player isn't fit, I'll say so.

final_quotes.speaker: Mikel Arteta
final_quotes.quote_raw: do their homework
final_quotes.quote_summary: Opponents should prepare thoroughly before facing us.
final_quotes.invalid_reason: Quoted text is not a meaningful quote from a public figure.

final_quotes.speaker: Gerard Pique
final_quotes.quote_raw: My formation would be 3-2-1 because it's the one that I think works better for the King's league format. I would choose Iker Casillas in goal. The three in the back I would say [Carlos] Puyol, Rio Ferdinand and myself. Then in the midfield I would say [Andres] Iniesta and Cesc Fabregas. Up front, Leo Messi
final_quotes.quote_summary: My ideal seven-a-side formation is 3-2-1 with Casillas, Puyol, Ferdinand, myself, Iniesta, Fabregas, and Messi.

final_quotes.speaker: Gerard Pique
final_quotes.quote_raw: I have to choose one striker Leo and Cristiano, I decide for Leo.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Between Messi and Ronaldo, I choose Messi for striker.

final_quotes.speaker: Gerard Pique
final_quotes.quote_raw: Ferdinand and Puyol been important for me in a personal way. I was really young when I joined Manchester United, and Rio helped me with that. Also when I joined Barcelona, I was 21, and Puyol was captain, and he also helped me a lot to start my career. Those two have been two incredible centre-backs.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Ferdinand and Puyol were crucial in my early career, both offering invaluable support at Manchester United and Barcelona, respectively.

final_quotes.speaker: Gerard Pique
final_quotes.quote_raw: I'll say Cesc Fabregas because he's like a brother, and, I think, in the Premier League, he's been one of the greatest; his first year at Arsenal was incredible. I would also say Iniesta because he won us the World Cup, and the goal is more than enough, but the quality he had is just amazing.
final_quotes.quote_summary: I'd pick Fabregas, who's like a brother and a Premier League great, and Iniesta, for his World Cup-winning goal and overall amazing quality.

final_quotes.speaker: Richard Keys
final_quotes.quote_raw: Every briefing coming out of OT [Old Trafford] underlines what a cataclysmic mistake it was keeping [Erik] ten Toast [Hag] last summer. They let him spend another £200m+ on rubbish & now there’s nothing for Amorim. Somebody in the brains trust should be fired. There’s nothing for Amorim to work with.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Keeping Ten Hag last summer was a huge mistake. He wasted over £200m on poor signings, leaving Amorim with no budget. Someone should be held accountable.

final_quotes.speaker: David Coote
final_quotes.quote_raw: Liverpool were s***.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Liverpool were bad.

final_quotes.speaker: David Coote
final_quotes.quote_raw: A c***. Absolute c***. Aside from having a right pop at me when I refereed them against Burnley in lockdown, then he accused me of lying and then just had a right f***ing pop at me. I've got no interest in speaking to somebody who's f***ing arrogant.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Jurgen Klopp is an arrogant person who criticized and accused me of lying. I don't want to communicate with him.

final_quotes.speaker: PGMOL
final_quotes.quote_raw: David Coote has been suspended with immediate effect pending a full investigation. PGMOL will be making no further comment until that process is complete.
final_quotes.quote_summary: David Coote has been suspended pending investigation. No further comment.
final_quotes.invalid_reason: Speaker is an organization, not a person.

final_quotes.speaker: Jamie Carragher
final_quotes.quote_raw: He’s done something stupid, you can imagine what the fella’s going through. I don’t want that, talking about cancel culture, but my point being is how could he then – he could never referee a Liverpool game, but how could he then do a rival?
final_quotes.quote_summary: Coote's actions were foolish, and while I don't support cancel culture, his comments make it hard for him to referee Liverpool or their rivals.

final_quotes.speaker: Jamie Carragher
final_quotes.quote_raw: The thing I despise most about social media is not people giving me stick, it’s when a referee makes a decision and that whole fan base is like ‘the world’s against us’. My own fan base are like that, but whoever it is, I can’t get into my head that a referee’s like that because you’d never sleep. I just think because of what he said about Liverpool, I think it’s make it difficult. I don’t want to see anyone cancelled.
final_quotes.quote_summary: I hate how fans on social media react to referee decisions, claiming bias. I can't imagine a referee being intentionally biased. Coote's comments complicate things, but I don't want him cancelled.

final_quotes.speaker: Caoimhin Kelleher
final_quotes.quote_raw: I made it clear in the last few years that I want to go somewhere and be a number one. The club has made that decision to get a goalkeeper (Mamardashvili) which makes it look like they’ve made a decision to go another direction. Liverpool have rejected a few bids as well. It’s not always in my hands to fully make the decision. My ambition is clear. I’m good enough & I want to go and play week in, week out.
final_quotes.quote_summary: I've always wanted to be a starting goalkeeper, and Liverpool's decision to sign another goalkeeper suggests they're going in a different direction.  Although they've rejected bids for me, my goal remains to play regularly.

final_quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim
final_quotes.quote_raw: You could like it or not, I don’t know, but you will see an idea [against Ipswich]. You will see a positioning. You will see something that we want to reach… that kind of level. You will feel that.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Against Ipswich, regardless of your opinion, you'll see my team's developing game plan and target level.

final_quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim
final_quotes.quote_raw: We have to know that it’s like two trainings before the first match. This is the best league in the world. But if I have to say something to you, [it’s that] you will see an idea. This I can guarantee.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Despite limited training before the match in this demanding league, I guarantee you'll see my team's strategic approach.

final_quotes.speaker: Ruben Amorim
final_quotes.quote_raw: We know that we need time, but we have to win time. To win time is to win games. But the most important thing for me is identity. So since day one we will start with our identity. Of course we are going to prepare the games, but we will focus a lot in our game model. How to play, how to press, these small things, small details. You cannot go 100% on every detail because it will be confusing for the players. If I have to say one thing, my main goal, my first goal, is identity.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Winning requires establishing our identity. From the start, we focus on our game model, how we play and press. Too much detail can be confusing, so establishing our identity is the primary goal.

final_quotes.speaker: Darragh Ennis
final_quotes.quote_raw: Can you beat a quiz by The Menace? This time it's a football quiz and it's on the Premier League in the 2020s. I bet you won't get all five!
final_quotes.quote_summary: Think you can beat my Premier League quiz on the 2020s? I bet you won't get all five right!

final_quotes.speaker: Darragh Ennis
final_quotes.quote_raw: So, how did that go? Are you like Rodri or more of a plonker like Rodney Trotter?
final_quotes.quote_summary: So, how'd you do? Are you a Premier League pro like Rodri, or more like Rodney Trotter?

final_quotes.speaker: Carlo Ancelotti
final_quotes.quote_raw: I was worried before and during the match. I’m not worried anymore now. Endrick had courage in that last ball of the match. The best solution was to take advantage of the three against one, but he was convinced. He did it very well. It was the most complicated solution, but it worked out very well for him. He is capable of doing things that no one can think of. At least, I didn't think of that. He has the gift of being very effective. You can see that he has something special. And a very strong and very fast shot.
final_quotes.quote_summary: I was initially worried about Endrick's performance, but his courageous play and effective finishing impressed me. He has a special talent and a powerful shot.

final_quotes.speaker: Endrick
final_quotes.quote_raw: focused on daily work until his opportunity arrives
final_quotes.quote_summary: I'm concentrating on training every day and waiting for my chance.

final_quotes.speaker: Paul Pogba
final_quotes.quote_raw: It has been a privilege to pull on the shirt of the Bianconeri and to share so many special moments together. I cherish the memories we made. They live on. Even in the most difficult moments over the past year, your support was crucial and I want to thank Juve fans around the world for their compassion. I am looking forward to the next chapter of my career and to stepping out on the pitch with my next club.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Playing for Juventus was an honor, with cherished memories. Fan support was vital during tough times. I'm excited for the next stage in my career.

final_quotes.speaker: Nicolas Pepe
final_quotes.quote_raw: Playing for Arsenal is still a huge part of my career. Playing with The Gunners, it’s unforgettable. I won titles [the FA Cup and the Community Shield] with this great club, so it was far from a bad experience. I still remember the good things. The Arsenal chapter, I won’t say it’s behind me. It’s, above all, something I’ll carry with me until the end of my career.
final_quotes.quote_summary: My time at Arsenal, including winning the FA Cup and Community Shield, remains a significant and positive part of my career.

final_quotes.speaker: Nicolas Pepe
final_quotes.quote_raw: At the time, I had a discussion with Unai Emery that lasted almost an hour. He explained to me how he wanted me to fit into the team, and obviously, it convinced me.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Unai Emery's hour-long discussion about my role in the team convinced me to join.

final_quotes.speaker: Nicolas Pepe
final_quotes.quote_raw: Honestly, I’ve turned the page. I have no rancour. Frankly, I wish Mikel Arteta the best.
final_quotes.quote_summary: I've moved on from Arsenal without resentment and wish Arteta well.

final_quotes.speaker: Cole Palmer
final_quotes.quote_raw: I give them [the medals] to my mum.
final_quotes.quote_summary: I gave my medals to my mother.

final_quotes.speaker: Cole Palmer
final_quotes.quote_raw: I wanted to restock.
final_quotes.quote_summary: I wanted to make room for more awards.

final_quotes.speaker: Cole Palmer
final_quotes.quote_raw: Clear them out so I can stock up again.
final_quotes.quote_summary: I'm clearing out space for new silverware.

final_quotes.speaker: Cole Palmer
final_quotes.quote_raw: The feeling you get when you win… you just want it again. You don’t want to stop and never get that feeling again.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Winning is such a great feeling that I want to experience it again and again.

final_quotes.speaker: Rúben Amorim
final_quotes.quote_raw: We know that we need time, but we have to win time. To win time is to win games. But the most important thing for me is identity. So since day one we will start with our identity. Of course we are going to prepare the games, but we will focus a lot in our game model. How to play, how to press, these small things, small details. You cannot go 100% on every detail because it will be confusing for the players. So if I have to say one thing, my main goal, my first goal, is identity.
final_quotes.quote_summary: We need time to rebuild, and winning games buys us that time. However, establishing a clear team identity is my top priority from the start.

final_quotes.speaker: Rúben Amorim
final_quotes.quote_raw: That’s for sure. That’s why we are Manchester United. That’s why we are … a long time ago, we don’t win the Premier League. But if you ask, Manchester United is the biggest club in England. So this is part of the history, it is not now. So we have to address that, to show that and to try to win again.
final_quotes.quote_summary: Manchester United's history as England's biggest club is undeniable, but it's in the past. We must acknowledge it, but our focus is on reclaiming our winning ways.

final_quotes.speaker: Rúben Amorim
final_quotes.quote_raw: When Manchester United talked to me, Omar, they told me about their plans and you get excited. It’s a real honour because I was the first choice to start that path. So it’s a great responsibility. But you feel honoured and excited to be part of that. And we know that if the team plays well and wins games, ­everything looks so much better and the people really start to believe in the new stadium and new ideas. So, we know that we are the engine of the football. Manchester United is the engine of the Premier League in my opinion.
final_quotes.quote_summary: I was excited by the club's plans. Being their first choice is an honor and a responsibility. Our performance will drive belief in the new stadium and ideas. Manchester United drives the Premier League.

final_quotes.speaker: Rúben Amorim
final_quotes.quote_raw: It’s hard to explain. It’s strange because it’s a feeling of belonging at the first day. And I know that it’s going to be tough. I know it’s a massive ­challenge, but I feel quite relaxed. I feel at home and I think that is important in the beginning. So, I’m very excited.
final_quotes.quote_summary: It's a strange feeling of belonging from day one, despite knowing the tough challenge ahead. I feel at home and excited.

final_quotes.speaker: Ruud van Nistelrooy
final_quotes.quote_raw: To everyone at Manchester United Football Club, in particular the ­backroom staff, the players and the fans. I want to thank you from the bottom of my heart for your incredible efforts and support. It has been a privilege and honour to ­represent the club as a player, coach and manager, and I will always cherish the memories we have shared together. @ManUtd will always have a special place in my heart, and I hope there are many more glory days at Old Trafford very soon – not only because I want the club to do well, but because you all deserve it!
final_quotes.quote_summary: Thank you to everyone at Manchester United for your efforts and support. It's been a privilege to represent the club, and I cherish our shared memories. I hope for more glory days at Old Trafford soon, you deserve it.
